PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer him to his admission this morning that the stock market decline would affect world growth and that that would have an impact on Australia's balance of payments and domestic demand. Does the Treasurer agree that investment, jobs and the Budget deficit are also likely to be affected and, therefore, that the strategy behind the Government's last Budget has been significantly undermined?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no. The strategy has not been significantly affected. What I said this morning was that it may be a consequence of this collapse in capital values on the stock market that consumer spending, consumer confidence and investor confidence in the United States of America come off somewhat. If that were to happen it may slow down the growth of the United States economy. However, I remind the House that last Thursday's statistics of its national accounts for the quarter showed that the American economy was growing a lot faster than the American Government wanted it to grow and that it is growing from the wrong places-growing from consumption.

ANSWER.PARA: I also remind the House that when I returned I said that I thought the world was going to be growing faster than we had originally contemplated in the Budget. That is a view with which the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) concurs. If the world were to slow down somewhat, that potential slow-down may be such as only to correct the more bullish assumptions for world growth-that is, assumptions more bullish than we had originally had factored into our own Budget and economic strategy. So in saying that, I thought that I was saying the obvious. I made the next link point that even if world growth slows down somewhat, world trade has been growing faster than world growth. It is possible that that could have some impact upon our exports. It is also possible that the shake-out in our own stock exchange will have some impact upon Australian consumption spending. That can also have an offsetting balancing impact upon the current account. In short, it is just a bit too early to say what we think all these impacts will be. That is why I said at the interview-I thought eloquently-that we are not running around, as Opposition members are doing, like chooks with our heads chopped off trying to find the policy settings for 9 o'clock this morning and perhaps another lot for 9 o'clock tomorrow morning. That is the sort of stuff that we see.
I noticed that the Leader of the Opposition, in reply to a question on a radio interview, `When you say tighten fiscal policy, what do you mean?', said:

. . . cutting spending further because one of the effects of the stock market fall could well be that revenue collections will not be as great and if the revenue collections are not as great then the deficit will grow and some adjusting action on the spending side will be necessary to make up the lost revenue.

We do not think the revenue collections will decline as a result of this activity. As I said last week, all the company income revenue has lagged by one year off the 1986-87 income, and all the other bases in the tax system are growing pretty much along with our budgetary expectations, indeed, one or two are growing faster. So, if the only rationalisation for another round of spending cuts from the Leader of the Opposition is that he thinks that the revenue is not going to cut the mustard, I think he is going to be wrong about that and, therefore, this whole phoney rationale for another round of budgetary cuts is just a knee-jerk response from an outfit that does not have any original ideas.

Let me just say a couple of things about economic conditions and policy. As I said a couple of minutes ago, we will be making our assessment of the fall-out of this change over the next few weeks. The Government has already achieved a substantial windback in fiscal policy more rapidly than any other OECD country and in that sense one deplores hearing comment not just from the Opposition but also from the media as though our fiscal position is the same as that of the United States; it is not, our fiscal position has been ambitiously changed for the better and one has to comprehend the Australian policy settings in terms of the change in that fiscal and wage setting. There will be no mini-Budget during the remainder of calendar year 1987 and, as is usual, the Government will consider the option of a statement of initial budgetary measures-in other words, a May-type statement-at the appropriate time which is, of course, early next year. So whether the option to proceed with a May-type statement is taken up will depend on a range of factors to be weighed much closer to that time.

Let me conclude on this point. Every day we hear the Leader of the Opposition on any radio station that will talk to him-which is most because they know he will talk to them-say that Australia has to make these rapid and offsetting adjustments. In my last visit a week or two ago to the Northern Hemisphere, in almost every place I went-Germany, Britain, the United States and France-people in financial institutions and official organisations were talking about the speed of the Australian economic changes. I just make the point to the Leader of the Opposition that last Wednesday in the Wall Street Journal, which would have been probably the most read paper in the country on that day, was an article headed `Australia points the way'. Let me read a bit of this to those people on that side of the chamber; I know they love this sort of stuff like a dose of castor oil, but they should listen anyway. The article states:

As the recent recovery of the Australian dollar will testify, a country does not have to fully eliminate a balance of payments deficit in order to enjoy a recovery in foreign demand of its currency after a confidence crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why our market fell after that report.
—The right honourable gentleman should just listen to this. It continues:

ANSWER.PARA: It simply has to develop an economic strategy that is credible and shows some clear signs of progress towards shrinking its external deficit. After experiencing a major currency crisis during the summer of 1986, Australia regained investor confidence through three different policy adjustments.

It goes on to talk about the three adjustments-wages, fiscal, et cetera. The article merely reflects the current state of mind in the Northern Hemisphere about Australia and this Government. If those opposite want to get up and talk with any credibility about policy settings-we have this position--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that the Treasurer has been speaking for 10 minutes and he is now repeating himself.

—Having gone to an election and lost-and this is a view being put particularly by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition-the Opposition thinks it is now dealing with a clean sheet of paper, and can make criticisms of the Government's economic policy in a vacuum. It believes that there is a clean sheet of paper, because it has lost the election, and that it can start from scratch. That is wrong; there is a big black blotch right in the middle called `election policy'. Then there are black blotches all around called `former economic performance as a Government'. By the time one gets through the big black blotch in the middle called `election policy' and the black blotches around the outside called `former economic performance in government', there is no white space left.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports that Dr Terry Metherell, a prominent member of the New South Wales Opposition, has queried the effectiveness of this Government's Priority One program, and that the New South Wales Education Minister, Mr Cavalier, believes that it was a mistake to establish what he called `another separate institution to cope with youth unemployment', rather than directing the relevant funds through the technical and further education (TAFE) system? Will the Minister inform the House of the progress that the Government has made in the area of improving young people's education, employment and training prospects as announced by the Prime Minister in 1985?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One does not normally take much notice of what Opposition members in State parliaments might say about this or any other matter, but I was concerned to find Rodney Cavalier echoing some of these thoughts. The point is that there has been a very substantial improvement in the prospects for young people both in the education system and in the labour market and all our efforts, from the launch of Priority One onwards, have been dedicated towards one single objective, and that is ensuring that there are better opportunities, particularly for young people. If we are to compare one of the widest measures, we find that since the election of this Government, the teenage level of unemployment has come down from 26 per cent to 21 per cent-a very substantial improvement indeed, given the circumstances in which we find ourselves. If we take into account the number of young people who are in the education system, we find that the teenage level of unemployment is not much different from that for the community as a whole.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose that the most important thing about this point is that Priority One was never just about traineeships, as impressive as they have been. Over the last few years, we have seen a very impressive build-up in the number of young people enrolled in traineeships and if we look forward to the end of this year, we expect to see some 20,000 young people involved in traineeships during this financial year. What is important about recent developments is that not only are young people recognising more and more the importance of traineeships, and not only are employers recognising, particularly in the private sector, the advantage of traineeships, but also an increasing number of trade unions are seeing traineeships as a very important way of recruiting young people into the work force. Through the work of my predecessor Ralph Willis, and many of his State colleagues, particularly among those such as Pat Hills in New South Wales itself, we have seen traineeships build to make a great contribution to increased opportunities for young people. Nearly half of the traineeships in Australia are in New South Wales and Rodney might talk to Pat about his views about the important contribution that traineeships are making to young people.

One of the difficulties in having separate Ministers for education and training is that sometimes they construct this rivalry between TAFE colleges and other kinds of training programs. I want to make the point that traineeships as a whole will ensure that, by the middle of 1988, about $30m will have found its way into TAFE systems throughout Australia, as a means of providing training opportunities for the trainees. Indeed, over 80 per cent of the training for trainees is provided through TAFE colleges, and I would expect that trend to continue. As well as that, if we look across the range of training programs in which we are involved, we see that something like $70m or $80m coming from the Commonwealth is finding its way into TAFE colleges, which are run by State governments.

Finally, we have seen secondary retention rates increase quite dramatically under this Government from a percentage figure in the high thirties up to the high forties in terms of the proportion of young people starting and completing secondary school. One of the great contributions to that improvement has been the great enhancement that we have been able to bring through Austudy. We now find that of some 215,000 people receiving Austudy, some 94,000 are in secondary education, and that figure is up substantially from last year.

That means that for poorer families-those in the lower socio-economic group-Austudy is becoming a major contributor to increasing the retention rates for young people from those poorer families. Typically, those children would have left school as soon as possible to take their chance in an uneasy job market or go on to the unemployment benefit, but they now find that they will be rewarded to the same extent by remaining in school. We now find that the participation rate among poorer families is equal to the participation rate for middle income families. That is a substantial improvement and one of which we are justly proud. It is improving equity enormously in terms of educational opportunity, and that was one of the important objectives of Priority One. I think it is time that Priority One was recognised for its very great success to date, and that will increase in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer, and I refer him to reports this morning that part of the rescue package to save Rothwells Ltd comprises a loan from a bank backed by Western Australia's Labor Government. Will the Treasurer clarify the extent to which public moneys have been used by the Western Australian Government to back up financial institutions such as Rothwells and in particular to what extent is the Commonwealth Government acting as an implicit guarantor for the loans backed by the Western Australian Government?

—I am not familiar with all the details of Rothwells' financing or its structure, apart from what I have read in the newspapers. The position is that the Commonwealth has made it clear to the trading banks that it will provide liquidity if needs be where a trading bank encounters difficulty with a client and where the fundamentals of the client are such and where support by that bank is such that the difficulties can be overcome. What we have seen in relation to Rothwells is an interest on the part of the Western Australian Government to protect depositors-who in the main are Western Australians-from what in old fashioned terms is a run on the institution, and following that a restructuring of Rothwells' assets and some support through underwriting by major companies in the market-place.
—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. What arrangements are being made by the Department of Social Security to promote the Government's family allowance supplement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to this question I make it clear to Parliament that the administrative arrangements with respect to reforms concerning family income assistance will be phased in over two years. I think it is important to say that some honourable members have raised with me a confusion about who will receive the family allowance supplement in December of this year. I want to make it clear that in terms of income, people who are in the social security system, people receiving additional pension and additional benefit, will receive that payment but at a higher level taking account of the increases announced in the Budget. Those families will receive $22 a week rather than $17 a week, the current payment, or where there is an older child, $28 a week. Similarly, the follow-up with respect to people who are currently in receipt of family income supplement will be done by the Department of Social Security and such recipients will not need to take any initiative. Furthermore, the Department will be issuing advices to people so that it is clear that they have received that increase.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the Government, in introducing this new family allowance supplement, has in mind particularly the needs of working families and a campaign will be carried out from the middle of November through to the middle of December designed initially to advertise and promote the existence of the family allowance supplement insofar as it relates to working families because quite clearly those families will need to apply to the Department of Social Security to receive that payment. In particular, apart from general publicity, an attempt will be made by the Department of Social Security to contact employers, trade unions and particularly schools and community groups to make sure that people generally in the community are aware of the existence of the payment.

There will be targeted strategies to inform ethnic communities. The leaflet concerning the supplement will be printed in 25 languages. A particular effort will go into communication in relation to Aboriginal communities, particularly using radio in the north of Australia in different Aboriginal languages. For the first time we have designed an information leaflet with a tear-off coupon, postage paid, which families can send away for an application form to be posted to their home. The target is to reach 200,000 families with 440,000 children by the end of this financial year. We are aiming in that initial campaign, which of course will need to continue through next year, to make sure that as many families as possible receive the child payment by Christmas.

We are seeking to contact working families about the new payment but of course, as I suggested earlier, a very large number of families-something like 400,000 families, with 740,000 children-who are currently in the social security system will receive that payment on advice before Christmas. I do not think I need to remind the House how significant the gains in this package are for low income families and I know that in the debate last week some interest was shown, I think from both sides of the House, in the new scheme and I hope that all members of parliament will do what they can to ensure that the family allowance supplement is very well known, particularly by working families in their electorates.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr N.A. Brown

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support whether he recalls the words of the Menzies report into the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd contract that:

INTERJECT.PARA: The watchwords for a Commonwealth purchasing agency are-best value for money, probity, fair dealing, equal opportunity and public accountability.

Can the Minister explain why none of those principles was followed when the Minister's Department, with his approval, recently gave to the lucky licensee of the duty free concessions at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport a three-year extension to its five-year contract without putting the contract for that extension out for public tender? Why were no public tenders called? Will the Minister now, before it is too late, follow the Menzies recommendation in the Amann case and in this case direct his Department to cancel the secret deal that it has made and put this multi-million dollar contract out for public tender?

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter, as I recall, involved a contract at the international terminal at Sydney. The international terminal at Sydney, as the honourable member would know, is being upgraded at a cost of many millions of dollars. The concession, I understand, was extended by three years because there had been considerable disruption to the business arrangements at that terminal. As a result of that, an arrangement was entered into which was thought appropriate in the circumstances. It is intended that that contract will be put out to public tender at the end of this time. The extension was given in the circumstances of the disruption that had occurred. It seems to me that, in those circumstances, that was an appropriate thing to do.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that, following the plunge on stock exchanges, the Minister supported a week's adjournment of the national wage case? Will the Minister now urge the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to resume the case so as not to penalise further the Australian work force for the gambling habits of the elite gentlemen belonging to the wealthy minority?

—I thank the honourable member for his question without notice. The position of the Government in this matter has been quite clearly stated. We sought a week's delay in the opening of the national wage case because the case was due to commence the day after the spectacular events on the international and Australian stock exchanges. The Government needed time to assess the possible impact of that on the real economy. That assessment is being undertaken. The Government will consider this matter prior to Wednesday and make its decision accordingly about what it thinks should happen to the national wage case.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It refers to his oft-repeated self-congratulations on the Hawke Government not having increased the $20 departure tax. Is it not a fact that international travellers will now pay a total of $25 into Federal Government coffers, thanks to the introduction of a $5 entry tax in this year's Budget? Does the new $5 tax therefore amount in practice to little more than a 25 per cent increase in the departure tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —With some justification, I think, I have said quite often that the Government has not increased the $20 departure tax, which was introduced by the previous Government, I think in 1980 at $10, was increased in 1981 to $20 and would, no doubt, had that Government stayed in office, now be a multiple of that.
—Oh, come on!
—Can the honourable member deny those facts? I do not think he can.
—The Minister will get on with answering the question.

—This Government made a very firm decision when we first came to office that we were not about to increase that figure. From 1983 to 1987, despite increases in costs and in the consumer price index, that figure has not increased. The extra $5 for the visa is in the nature of cost recovery. Most other countries have a similar charge. Given that the cost of an air fare to Australia is about $1,500, I do not think that anybody will be put off a trip to Australia because of a charge of $5 for the reissuance of a visa.
—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade confirm that the United States House of Representatives recently passed a resolution in favour of United States signature of the Treaty of Rarotonga?

—On 20 October, the United States House of Representatives approved, without objection, a `sense of the Congress' resolution urging the President of the United States to reconsider his decision not to sign the protocols to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. The resolution noted, firstly, that the treaty was fully consistent with ANZUS and with United States security commitments in the South Pacific; secondly, that it satisfied established United States criteria for nuclear weapon free zones; and, thirdly, that the signature and ratification of the protocols would be in the national interest of the United States. Naturally, the Government is pleased and encouraged by this resolution of the United States House of Representatives. We sincerely trust that the United States Administration will review its earlier decision not to sign those protocols, in particular in the light of this expression of the `sense of the Congress'.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Following the Prime Minister's promise of a compact or treaty with Aborigines, I ask: Has even the most basic outline of such a document been formulated by either his office or his Department? If not, will the Government ever meet, and in what form, the expectations it has so cynically raised?

—It is not a cynical exercise in which the Government is engaged. No document has been prepared by the Government. As the Prime Minister has outlined, what we are going to do, though, is to engage in dialogue with the Aboriginal community, and other members of the community, to reach an agreement.
—All words and no action.

—The comment was made, `All words and no action'. The point about this is that if members of the Opposition joined with honourable members on this side of the chamber, we could reach agreement on this all important issue. I say to the questioner that here is an opportunity for this country to settle down, for us to discuss this issue with people rationally and try to reach agreement. If honourable members opposite let this opportunity go and call it a cynical exercise, I think that they will be roundly condemned by the rest of the nation and the world.

—I address my question to the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs. Does he agree that the rate of teenage unemployment, which stood at 21 per cent in September 1987, is unacceptably high? What measures does the Government propose to deal with this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. Yes, the Government does regard that figure of 21 per cent as unreasonably high. It ought to be remembered that when we came to office in April 1983, the youth unemployment figure stood at 26.4 per cent. Although we have reduced that figure, we still believe that there is a considerable distance to go. Caution should generally be used in referring to statistics on youth unemployment because the figure can vary quite considerably at various parts of the year, for example, during school holidays. The proportion of those in the 15- to 19-year group looking for full time work is currently only about 8 per cent. That is related partly to the emphasis that the Government is placing at two levels. The first is to encourage younger people to stay in school longer rather than join the work force. There has already been a considerable degree of success in that regard. The other is the development of our traineeship programs. We expect that in 1987-88 some 20,000 young Australians will participate in traineeship programs. That is a considerable achievement.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out that all of those traineeship programs involve quite considerable and complicated negotiations with employers and unions in order to produce arrangements which can then be followed up by my Department. We believe that negotiations which are currently under way with key unions will produce a situation in which we can expect a considerable upturn in the near future in the figures that I have already given the honourable gentleman.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: PILOTS AND PILOT INSTRUCTORS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel: What steps has the Government taken to address the inevitable safety considerations resulting from the extraordinary wastage of trained pilots and pilot instructors from the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I know that he is concerned about this issue, mainly because Williamtown is in his electorate. He raised during the consideration of the Estimates these sorts of issues and his concern that some people were leaving Williamtown. I am happy to tell him that some of the people who had actually notified their resignation have since withdrawn that notification.

ANSWER.PARA: I assure him and other members that there will be no reduction in RAAF readiness, RAAF capabilities or safety standards of operational crews. The Chief of the Air Staff has directed that RAAF flying training be given priority. I emphasise that point: training is to be given priority. RAAF activities will be adjusted as a short term measure to provide the additional resources for training. Reductions in operational activities will be only temporary and probably only marginal in terms of total flying hours.

The retention of qualified flying instructors governs the rate at which RAAF pilots can be trained. The RAAF is presently urgently reviewing its qualified flying instructor and pilot training requirements as a launching base for recovery.

I made some points in the House last Thursday, which I now reiterate in order to highlight some of the positive things that this Government is doing to address this very serious problem. We are working towards increasing to 55 years the compulsory retiring age for pilots with the rank of wing commander and below. We are working towards introducing a limited air crew specialisation, which will allow an extended flying career for selected officers, and adopting policies designed to widen promotional opportunities for non-pilots in areas such as personnel and materiel, thus reducing the demand for pilots in staff posts.
This Government is addressing the problem. We acknowledge that it is a problem, and we are putting policies in place to ensure that the problem is overcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs: Will the Government ensure that totally and permanently incapacitated (T and PI) pensioners continue to receive their benefits after the age of 65, subsequent to a Federal Court of Australia decision which called into doubt the validity of the benefits? Will veterans receive benefits pending legislative action by the Government?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I know he is very concerned about the T and PI pensioners, not only in his electorate but throughout Australia. I know that many T and PI pensioners were concerned that they would lose their pension after the age of 65 after the Federal Court decision. The Government has decided to amend the Veterans' Entitlements Act to ensure that all of those veterans receiving the T and PI pension will receive their pension for the whole of life. We have been promised a speedy passage of the Bill through the Parliament by the Leader of the Opposition.

—Did the Treasurer issue a Press statement on 6 July, just five days before the election, while campaigning in Chisholm, to the effect that an office of the Australian Taxation Office could be opened in the electorate, which at that time was the most marginal Government-held electorate in the country? Did the Treasurer claim that the proposed office would employ 500 to 600 people and provide a vastly improved service to the people of the electorate? Does the Treasurer intend to proceed with his pre-election proposal? If not, does he agree that he misled the people of Chisholm with a cynical pre-election promise that he never intended to fulfil?

—I do not know what the honourable member is complaining about; it did not work. The Australian Taxation Office is going through a process of decentralisation away from these large centralised structures which have been generally located in the central business districts, where rentals have been at very high levels and where simply the provision of physical space has become a problem in any of the buildings that are likely to be currently leased and where free space becomes available or in any of the new areas. As well as that, of course, we have had the administrative inefficiencies of having these very large groups of people there, plus the staff difficulties of people travelling from various parts of the suburbs of the cities to the central business areas. In the last few years we have seen the opening of regional offices, in Melbourne and, in New South Wales, in Newcastle. There is another one opening soon in Chatswood, there is one which the Tax Office believes-the Government agrees-it would be in its best interests to open in that region of Melbourne; and also another in the south-western area of Sydney. They are decentralisation objectives which the Tax Office still has very firmly in its view. It has been in the process of evaluating accommodation and, at the same time, testing with its staff their willingness to serve in the various regional offices. But I cannot say any more about that now.

—Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to newspaper reports in the Illawarra Mercury on Friday, 23 October and Saturday, 24 October which indicate his support for the plans of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) to shed a further 2,600 jobs at the Port Kembla steelworks? Are these reports correct?

—They are not correct. What I said was reflecting upon both the decision of BHP and the requirements on BHP under the steel industry plan for any shedding of labour at its steel establishments to occur by attrition rather than by retrenchment. Indeed, that has been occurring and will occur into the future. The other point I made was that if we are to continue to compete in the world in terms of the competitiveness of Australian steel, obviously the steel industry's productivity will continue to need to rise. We have seen a fairly healthy lift in the profitability and productivity of the Australian steel industry; but, as fast as we have been going, some other countries have been going faster. In other words, nothing is static; everyone else is moving too. That implies continuing improvements in management and work practices at Australian steel establishments. I made the obvious point that, given the fact that world steel production is fairly static, for productivity to improve for a given level of production implies, over time, a smaller work force. That is implicit in the BHP announcement, but the Government is saying that that must be in line with the attrition clause of the steel industry plan. In an economy in which the Government has fostered faster employment growth, in the past those lay-offs have been taken up in other industries in other parts of those particular locations, plus the fact that there has been regional support in areas in which these steel industries exist. So it would be wrong-and was wrong-to take my views as some sort of blanket endorsement for a policy of slashing employment at the Port Kembla steelworks. I do not endorse that, but I do endorse over time the improved productivity of the steel industry by attrition and by changes to both management and work practices. I emphasise management practices because I think the management style of the steel industry is as important an issue as the work practices which have been unwound in the last few years. As a result of the occasion of my visit to Port Kembla for the opening of the new continuous slab cast from a rolling mill, one can be pleased by the $800m worth of investment and the ongoing investment at Port Kembla and say that it augurs well for the continuing competitiveness of the Australian steel industry.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to his previous statements, firstly, that the Government could raise more than $700m a year from death duties and, secondly, that not taxing deceased estates was inequitable. I ask: What is the basis for this revenue estimate? Does the Minister consider that a wealth tax would be a desirable complement, on both budgetary and equity grounds, to measures aimed at reducing corporate and high personal marginal tax rates?

—I do not know the source of the statement that was attributed to me, but let me say that certainly I support, and this Government supports-over and against and in contrast with the Opposition-equitable taxation policies. As I suggested last week, whenever we have sought to improve the overall equity and efficiency of the taxation system we have had nothing but opposition from those on the other side of the House. I feel very strongly about this issue if for no other reason than that in terms of the portfolio of social security we are determined to achieve a fiscal system that is appropriately balanced. This Government has taken measures to ensure that people who do not need social security payments do not receive them. It has also taken a series of measures to ensure that people who have not been paying their fair share of tax do so. As I said, I am not at all sure of the source of the statement in the honourable member's question.
—Did you say it or not?

—As far as I know, I did not. As I understand it, the honourable member attributed to me a statement in support of some particular measure relating to estate duty or death duty that might raise of the order of $700m. According to the various rates that might apply to inheritance taxes, of course we can raise very substantial amounts of money. In statements I have made in recent days in terms of advocacy of what government policy might be, I certainly have not made a statement as specific as that. I have pursued, and I will continue to pursue-I think all members of the Government will seek to do so-taxation policies which are equitable. Until the Opposition can convince the Australian electorate, as it failed to do in the most recent election, that it is in favour of equitable taxation policies it will remain in opposition. Whatever else may be said about the Australian electorate it is concerned to see much greater fairness than the erosion of the tax base that occurred when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, call on the Federal Government to give notice to terminate the lease of the US base at Pine Gap before October 1986.
We believe that in the interests of world peace and the Australian people, this lease should be terminated and the base closed because Pine Gap is a spy base and a war base:

Since it was opened in 1969, it has eavesdropped on Australian telephone and telex communications. Information obtained in this way was used by the CIA to destabilise the Whitlam Government in late 1975.

It provides communication facilities of CIA in countries throughout the world, much of which is connected with overthrowing other country's governments. Last year it became clear Pine Gap was spying on Greece.
The electronic and photographic information its satellites receive is used to select nuclear targets in the territory of the Soviet Union and its allies.
Many US military activities short of nuclear war are also co-ordinated by Pine Gap.
These include the war against Vietnam and the invasion of Lebanon by US marines in 1984.
Pine Gap spends only a tiny percentage of its time monitoring arms control agreements, and even then the data gathered is so top-secret Australia has no access to it.
Pine Gap's role will be expanded under Reagan's Star Wars scheme to extend the arms race to outer space, threatening the existence of our planet.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need to recognise the vulnerability of the Australian economy to sudden shifts of world economic sentiment.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the 1987-88 Budget was brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) it was greeted by the Australian media, and by a large number of economic commentators, with one or two conspicuous exceptions, with almost universal praise and applause. We all remember the headlines about the 1987 Budget. The essential thesis of the Opposition at the time and, dare I say it, the essential thesis of a number of economic commentators who had looked beneath the surface, had worked out how the Budget aggregates had been arrived at and discovered such interesting facts as that the level of expenditure restraint in the May economic statement was a fraction tougher than the level of expenditure restraint in the Budget itself, was different. The reaction of those people and of the Opposition was rather more circumspect and cautious. Our attitude was summarised when I replied to the Budget on 17 September, a little over a month ago. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has brought down a Budget which seeks to paint a coat of veneer over a brittle and fragile economy. . . . My fear . . . and the fear of the Opposition, is that Labor's fifth Budget will not, as time passes, match the extravagant praise heaped upon it in recent days. . . . On behalf of the Opposition I simply say: Let the buyer beware.

What I was saying then and what the more prudent economic commentators were saying was: `Look beneath the surface and look at the economic context in which Australia was placed then and is placed now, and look at the fact that 40 per cent of our gross domestic product on an annual basis is represented by overseas debt, compared with a figure of 13 per cent in the Unite States of America'. That figure should be emblazoned on the consciousness of every Australian, irrespective of his or her politics, who is concerned about the economic future of this country.

What also should be emblazoned on the understanding of those same Australians is the fact that that figure has doubled in percentage terms over the past four years. In June 1983 it was 21 per cent of gross domestic product; it is now 41 per cent of gross domestic product. Those simple and unassailable facts are sometimes forgotten and sometimes ignored, in particular by the Treasurer and members of the Government as they shower themselves in self-praise about their alleged economic achievements. The attitude of the Government regarding the 1987 Budget was best summarised by none other then the Treasurer himself when he was interviewed on The Midday Show of 18 September. The Treasurer's words bear remembering at this time when he said: `This is the great coming of age of Australia. This is the golden age of economic change'. He was then asked: `How much credit do you take?' The Treasurer replied: `Oh, a very large part'. That was the end of the interview. If ever an exchange symbolised the besetting risk of this Government's economic approach, it is the supreme arrogance of the Treasurer as epitomised by that remark.

A Treasurer should have a proper understanding of the economic condition of this country. Realising that we are staring in the face an overseas debt which is 40 per cent of our gross domestic product and remembering that the Argentinean foreign debt in 1982 was only 29 per cent of gross domestic product and that the figure for the United States is only 13 per cent, we get some idea of the arrogance that besets this Government. Indeed, that is one of the mortal fears of the Opposition-and, I suspect, a growing number of the Australian community-that this Treasurer and this Government do not recognise that for a long time we have lived with policies that have taken the Australian economy to the edge of risk, that we have lived with policies that have responded too slowly to the need for economic change.

The relevant question to be asked in the wake of the enormous upheaval on world stock exchanges is not whether or not Australian stock exchanges should have fallen, although some will ask why it is that our fall was significantly greater than that of Wall Street and most other major exchanges. That is not the fundamental question to ask because no one could fairly say that government policy could have prevented a world collapse of stock markets from spreading to Australia. The fundamental question to ask ourselves is whether the policies that are being followed at the present time are forcing the pace of adjustment in the Australian economy quickly enough and whether they are firm enough and making the Australian economy lean enough to minimise to the extent possible the impact of external shocks on the Australian economy. The measure of effectiveness or otherwise of an Australian government of any political complexion in relation to its response to world economic adversity is the extent to which its domestic policies either speed the impact of that adversity or in fact slow it down.

Our argument all along has not been some naive, simplistic approach addressed to the proposition that because this happens overseas does not mean it will not have an effect on Australia. Of course it will, and governments before this Government have had to contend with adverse international economic developments and governments beyond this Government will have to contend with adverse international economic developments. But our complaint, our concern-and I believe this week the growing concern of a significant number of people in Australia-is that just as this Government and this Treasurer sat on their hands for 18 months from the beginning of 1985 until well into 1986 and did nothing about our deteriorating economy, they are going to do the same thing again. This is the Treasurer who authorised an approach to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in March of 1986 to support the 3 per cent superannuation claim knowing full well that his own Treasury had warned him six months earlier that we were facing a downturn in the terms of trade. Did he mention the downturn in the terms of trade in March 1986? Of course he did not, yet he would now seek to tell all of us, to tell the Australian public, that the main reason that the Australian economy has suffered adversity over the past couple of years is that downturn in the terms of trade. Our concern is that he will sit on his hands again and he will not recognise that one cannot live in the fool's paradise of imagining that some adjustment to economic policy might not be necessary as a result of the convulsions of the past few weeks.

We argued that that change was necessary before those convulsions. We said that the 1987 Budget took the Australian economy to the edge of risk. My colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has argued regularly over the past couple of months that the pace of adjustment of economic policy has not been rapid enough. All of those things were said before the events of the past couple of weeks and they were said again when we had that unexpectedly large current account deficit figure last Friday week, the largest September current account deficit in Australia's economic history. What is the response of the Treasurer? It is to say that anybody who raises the possibility of economic change in the face of events of the past couple of weeks is indulging in panic. Let me remind him that his own colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is not a very happy member of the Hawke Government at present. The poor old Minister for Industrial Relations worked for two years on trying to get his Hancock legislation up and then it was grabbed away from in front of him immediately before the election. A great debate is going on inside the Government as to whether it will be brought back. He is not a very happy member because he has had most of his marbles stolen by either the Treasurer or some other members of the Government. This is what he had to say on 23 October: `Well, no one is suggesting that wages should be tied to the stock exchange. Simply, what we looked at in the middle of this week was the collapse of stock exchanges around the world, and including Australia, with very large reductions in share prices with unknown ramifications for the real economy'. He went on to say, `I mean the whole array of effects could be very considerable and at this stage we have no idea of where it is all going to end'.

That was the summary, that was the thrust of what the Minister for Industrial Relations was saying. We say to the Government very simply and very quietly that the first thing that it ought to do is to abandon its unambiguous support for an across the board wage increase of 1.5 per cent. In the present economic circumstances one cannot support an unambiguous approach to the Arbitration Commission which says one supports that 1.5 per cent increase. There can be no justification for that. Wage increases based on productivity gains, wage increases that are earned, can be supported, but that kind of open-ended commitment to an across the board increase cannot be supported. Secondly, the Treasurer once again with his supreme arrogance says, `Oh, the downturn of the last few weeks is not going to have any impact at all upon the Budget revenues'. We will wait and see about that. We will wait and see whether the confidence that the Treasurer displayed on that occasion is borne out. We wonder whether he is right or whether Syntec Economic Services Pty Ltd is right.

Let me make another point about the major problem; that is, the imbalances of the rest of the world-the United States budget imbalance and the trade imbalances of the United States, Japan and Germany. Every time I have said that, I have been attacked by the Opposition for gratuitously giving advice to others, when it failed to comprehend that the very essence of the incorrection of these imbalances would lead to this kind of condition. It means that we have to be competitive and we have to maintain our competitiveness. That is why we have rapidly changed fiscal policy. That is why we have rapidly changed wages policy. That is why we are continuing to keep up, by way of these microeconomic changes, the efficiency and productivity of the Australian economy, so that, no matter how the world looks, we will be better able to cope with those conditions, eke our living out of the world economy and world trade, and take a larger share of it. The fact is that this Government will never be complacent about economic conditions. As I said today, we will maintain our vigilance in terms of the import of these changes, but we will not be panicked or rushed into mindless policy changes which may not be appropriate. Had they done that, we would have still been experiencing and would have still been able to experience rates of growth of the kind that we initially achieved.

When members of the Opposition talk about the situation that we face in Australia at present, I think what we need to do is to continue to remind them of the fact that when we came to government in March 1983 we inherited an economic desert, an economy which had been devastated as a result of the absurd, inconsistent and inadequate policies which they had been adopting. We had massive unemployment-10 1/2 per cent unemployment, representing 750,000 people-growing at the rate of 250,000 every year. We had double digit inflation of 11.5 per cent; we had negative growth for the first time in 30 years; and we had manufacturing industries which had been devastated by their artificially overvalued Australian dollar which brought such a flood of imports into Australia that industries in Australia were smashed against the wall. Factory after factory and company after company had been literally smashed against the wall.

When we came into government there was no manufacturing potential. We had widespread and growing poverty with the result that one person in every five, including 800,000 children, were identified in Australia, with all its magnificent potential, as living in poverty. Members of the coalition now try to teach us. The Australian people rejoice in the fact that we reject their advice. Those opposite have learnt nothing. We also had record levels of bankruptcy; shattered confidence; a blow out, as I have indicated, in the Budget deficit; and an over valued Australian dollar which was responsible for our industry being devastated.

In the period that the Hawke Labor Government has been in office, the results have been nothing short of spectacular. After 1975 there were seven years when the coalition Government had the opportunity to put into place effective and constructive policies that could have brought about a restructuring of the Australian economy and could have provided the basis for significant and continuing growth that would have been of continuing benefit to this and future generations, and they blew it! They were seven lost years as far as the potential of this country was concerned. In 4 1/2 years we have turned it about.

There is an air of confidence in the Australian community. DEBATE.TITLE: FISHING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1987[COGNATE BILLS:FISHING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AMENDMENT BILL 1987FISHING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill 1987 concurrently with the Fishing Industry Research Amendment Bill 1987 and the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: FISHING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill 1987, the Fishing Industry Research Amendment Bill 1987 and the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 is to strengthen the powers of fisheries inspectors under three existing Acts, to formalise fishing industry research under the Rural Industry Research Fund guidelines and to use surplus moneys from the existing Fishing Industries Research and Development Trust Fund to assist in the purchase of a new fisheries research ship for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). These Bills were actually presented to the House of Representatives prior to the dissolution of Parliament for the July election, and reached the Senate, but there was no resolution there in time, and hence the Bills are back here again before Parliament. To my understanding, the only differences to this legislation and the situation generally with that legislation is, first of all, the more definitive proposal for the research ship, in relation to what was being discussed and proposed earlier and, secondly, the heightened concern in the fishing industry over the additional charges and levies forced on the industry in the recent Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill makes administrative and procedural changes to the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968, the Fisheries Act 1952 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984. It is claimed that the Bill will streamline administrative actions in preparing notices containing prohibitions against certain activities within the fisheries covered by the Acts. It widens the powers of fisheries officers to search vessels or motor vehicles-in some cases this can be done without warrant-or enter land or premises, and tightens rules governing undersized fish catches. At the same time, provision is made for fish caught undersized or otherwise contrary to the Acts to be returned to the sea promptly, without penalty. I am not sure whether that penalty applies to the fish or to the person who caught the fish-it is a little hard to return a fish without penalty.

Because the Bill does extend powers of enforcement, and those powers of officers other than police officers, there is legitimate cause for concern by members on both sides of Parliament about legislation that, in any way, encourages or allows police powers to be used by officers other than those duly constituted for the enforcement of the well-being of the country and in the correct way. I have been advised that these particular additional powers were considered and approved by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills prior to the dissolution of Parliament for the election. The point should be made that, irrespective of whether a member of parliament is in the House of Representatives or in the Senate, he should have similar concern for the question of the powers of the individual versus the powers of officers, whoever those officers may be. I have no doubt that this will be considered again in the Senate. I am also aware of the particular problems of enforcement that can occur with fisheries and therefore of the need for powers for fisheries officers to ensure that the management of those fisheries is conducted in the appropriate way.

The Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill and the Fishing Industry Research Amendment Bill maintain the industry's research effort, but establish an administrative framework which closely resembles the rural industry research fund guidelines. A Research and Development Council is to be established to replace the current Fishing Industry Research Committee and it will comprise an independent chairperson, a Government member and three to seven representatives with industry expertise. Those with industry experience will be appointed by a selection committee comprising an independent chairperson-or chairman in my terminology-a member with experience in fisheries administration or management, a member experienced in fisheries research and development, a member nominated by the Australian Fisheries Council and three members nominated by the national Fishing Industry Research and Development Council.

I understand that the industry supports the changes and in fact is anxious that the new research arrangements be put in place as quickly as possible so that the allocation of research priorities for the next 12 months can come from the new committee rather than the old committee because there is a belief and a hope in the industry that perhaps the priorities for fisheries research under the new arrangement will be more commercially based or commercially oriented than was the case in the past. The research committee will produce a five-year plan for research and development plus annual operating programs-the usual procedure.

Unlike the other research arrangements with regard to primary industry commodities, no direct levy is placed on fishermen and then matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth Government. Because of the nature of the industry and the levy structure, the Commonwealth will be matching on a dollar-for-dollar basis up to one per cent of the gross value of industry production. Those matching funds are provided from State revenue rather than, as I said earlier, directly from fishermen-although it would have to be acknowledged that the States themselves as well as the Commonwealth collect levies and therefore the industry can claim that it is playing its part in the provision of levies or money for necessary research. As I said earlier, the further development in regard to the legislation that went through this House some months ago is that the Government has now decided to use the surplus funds in the old research account to acquire a new research vessel for the CSIRO Division of Fisheries Research.

I have been advised that at present there is about $6m in that account and that it will be put towards the cost of the new vehicle which could be as much as $15m to $20m. The present fisheries research vessel used by the CSIRO, the Soela, is leased from Kailis and France. There is no criticism from the industry or the Opposition about the need for a new research vessel, or for that matter more than one vessel when one looks at the area of potential for fisheries development in this nation and therefore the physical impossibility of one ship covering the area that needs to be covered for this purpose. However, there are two areas of concern: first, the lack of consultation in relation to the new vessel and, secondly, the general concern as to whether or not the CSIRO should be a ship operator as part of its responsibilities.

From a cost-benefit point of view and from the point of view of the CSIRO being able to concentrate on what it is there for-that is, research and not the running of research vessels-serious consideration should be given to a lease or management arrangement whereby the crewing and general operation of the ship is let out to an organisation such as Kailis and France-on this previous occasion-to actually operate the vessel and then allow the CSIRO to concentrate on that vessel and for that matter other vessels involved in the research operation.

However, there is greater concern in the industry in general terms over what it believes is the lack of consultation by the Department and the Government in relation to fishing matters generally, the dramatically increased levies and charges that are being imposed on the industry as a result of the Budget, and the lack of accountability by the Australian Fisheries Service of the Department of Primary Industry in relation to the expenditure of those levies from licence fees and so on that are charged on those who operate in the Commonwealth fisheries.

At present there are three Commonwealth managed fisheries: the Northern Prawn, the South-eastern Trawl and the Southern Bluefin Tuna. In the Budget it was announced that the attributable cost recovery for those three Commonwealth fisheries will increase from 44 per cent last year to 60 per cent this year, to 75 per cent next year and 90 per cent in the following year. In other words, over a period of about two years the cost to those with Commonwealth licences operating in those fisheries will double from about $1,500 to $3,000 per vessel. That is a dramatic increase and the industry has really had no ability to question whether that money is efficiently spent or how it could be spent more efficiently at the present level of the licence fee rather than what is perceived to be necessary by the Australian Fisheries Service to require that significant increase to occur. In addition, there is a completely new $295 levy of which, in my discussions with the fishing industry, only $8 can be discovered at this time, that is, the $8 charged for the operation of the National Fishing Industry Council. How will the remainder of that $295 be spent, because in a full year the total collected amounts to about $1.8m? That is a significant new impost on an industry which has no idea how that money will be spent and has no ability to question or alter the level of impost placed upon it.

I should also say that other levies and charges are imposed on the fishing industry at both Commonwealth and State levels. I believe that there is a great responsibility on the Australian Fisheries Service to declare how funds from the additional levy will be spent and whether or not it is an appropriate form of expenditure on behalf of the industry of this country. The Australian Fisheries Service should also say how it intends to expend the dramatically increased cost recovery percentage, because we face the same problem on cost recovery with the Department in this regard as do a whole range of primary industry export products with cost recovery on export inspection. It is a very nebulous statement that 50 per cent, for example, of the cost is attributable to export inspection cost recovery, because it is 50 per cent of what cost? That has never been identified. There is no budget for it and there is no list on it. I believe that it is a completely unfair situation for any industry to be required to pay 50 per cent of export inspection charges or 90 per cent of cost recovery on Commonwealth managed fisheries without ever being able to check and debate and, if necessary, alter what that actual magical 100 per cent is.

I have been advised that, for example, one of the charges levied by the AFS is an additional 84 per cent on-cost on behalf of itself and the States for services rendered. I would be pleased to hear from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in his reply to this debate whether that is a fact and, if so, how is the 85 per cent determined and, more particularly, how is it justified? I would also like the Minister to say whether it is a fact that the Australian Fisheries Service with 120 personnel is the biggest section in the Department. Is it becoming even larger with an additional 11 officers to be appointed this year?

How is it that that number is necessary, particularly now that the industry is being called on to pay for 90 per cent of the costs? How does this fit with the Government's general statement of reducing the cost of the Public Service to the general taxpayers of Australia by this so-called reduction of 3,000 people? If the Department is reducing its numbers-I have heard one figure of about 156-how does that fit with the overall level of personnel in the Department? Why is it so necessary to have these additional people? I note in the statement of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, released after the Budget under the heading `Fisheries Management and Development Programs', he explained:

There will . . . be a comprehensive review of the corporate and institutional arrangements associated with the development, implementation and maintenance of the Commonwealth's fisheries management programs. It is anticipated that the review will result in a more positive role and greater level of responsibility for the industry.

I have been advised that as yet the industry has not been consulted on any aspect of that review. I would welcome in the Minister's reply a statement on the position. What are the criteria for the review? Who are the personnel being appointed to the review? What input will the industry have? After all, the industry must have every right to be fully involved in a review of what is becoming a very expensive operation to that industry. I hope that in that review far greater account is taken not only of the accountability but also of the whole principle of who should be controlling Commonwealth fisheries. Should it be a department or should it be more deregulated? I acknowledge there is a need for a control in these fisheries but it should be a more self-managed operation; that is, the industry itself should manage their operation to a far greater degree than it is allowed to now and therefore would be directly responsible and accountable for the charges placed on that industry. I believe it is essential for the industry to be given the ability to self-manage those fisheries.

The industry already has an example before it. One can recall that before the dissolution for the election the Senate used its regulatory blocking power to block a most unsuitable proposal put forward by the Government in relation to surplus ships in the northern prawn fishery through an industry controlled buy-back arrangement. There is also some frustration in the industry at present in relation to that operation. There are accusations that the Department is not being as quick and as helpful as it could be to allow that scheme to be put in place. If the statement I have just made is incorrect I-and I am sure the industry-will be pleased to be advised in reply of the actual position at present. I believe it indicates in general terms the desire, the willingness, the ability of the industry to manage its own affairs to a far greater degree, particularly now that these additional imposts are being put on the industry. Nothing imposes more discipline in accountability and cost efficiency than people being forced to pay for the total-or close to the total-cost of an operation. The Opposition parties do not oppose the legislation but we do want these sincere and, I believe, significant questions that have been put by me-others will be put by other speakers-to be answered in this debate. We give notice that unless there is a significant move towards self-management within these Commonwealth fisheries that will be a high priority for the next coalition government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill is an important Bill for the fishing industry. The development of the Australian fishing industry under the Government has been a remarkable success because the Government has been game to make hard decisions in the fishing industry, as in many other areas of Australian government. For many sections of the industry there has been prosperity and success, not least because of the emphasis on research and development. I can recall five, six and seven years ago people coming to me with concerns, particularly for the future of the southern blue- fin tuna industry, the abalone industry and the Australian trawl industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In the electorate of Eden-Monaro those engaged in the trawl and long-line industries are now on a profitable basis and for the first time have a secure investment. But this success, Mr Deputy Speaker, has brought its own problems to which we must now pay heed. Secure investments attract investors, and these investors are people who can now afford to buy into the industry or, to put it another way, buy out the small operators. This concerns me a lot as the fishing industry in Eden-Monaro, where almost 70 per cent of the trawl is located, is based on the small operator. The large companies, including New Zealand interests, are in the financial position to engage highly paid lobbyists who are able to take advantage of the present encouragement by government of industry self-management. It is like the southern bluefin tuna saga all over again.

Fishermen need to keep a vigil and pay for lobbying even when things appear to be going well. An industry levy to ensure equal representation is one way of ensuring the fair and equitable development of the fishing industry which has been put on such a strong footing by the Hawke Government and particularly by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who made decisions that the previous Government was not game to make. I mention briefly consultations with the Royal Australian Navy, which need improving if the fishermen's concerns are to be taken properly into account. It is good to see the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) in the House at the moment. Fishermen would like to have meaningful consultation before this occurs. I am pleased that the Minister has acknowledged this and I am confident that she will take it up with the Department of Defence. Fishermen have themselves checked alternative areas in the same vicinity with echo-sounding systems that meet the Navy criteria. The proposed closures will mean the loss of the most productive trawl areas in the region and a substantial loss of fish for the Sydney domestic market, thus creating a demand for imported fish. The result will be a substantial impact on the livelihood of local fishing operators. Obviously, development needs to take into account adequate consultative mechanisms with the Navy and any other bodies having an impact on the fishing industry.

I conclude by saying that the fishing industry is urgently in need of attitudes that are oriented to a viable industry throughout Australia, not just through big owners but through the economically sensible operations of small owners. In my electorate, the Oceanfresh organisation has taken some amazing initiatives which I believe will result in a large degree of prosperity in the fishing sector in Eden. The co-operatives at Ulladulla and Eden and in other areas throughout Australia have also taken important initiatives. They have adapted to the times. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill, the Fishing Industry Research Amendment Bill and the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill, I would like first to talk about the size of the fishing industry in Australia and its importance to our economy. The fishing industry is a rapidly growing industry and one that is increasingly making a very large contribution to our exports. In 1986-87 the total exports of edible fish products rose by 22 per cent over the previous year to total $591m. Of interest in the growing fishing industry is the orange roughy, fields of which have been found in southern Australia, particularly in Bass Strait and around the coastal waters of Tasmania. I will come back to that matter in a minute as it is of particular interest to me because of the growth in the number of fishing boats coming out of the port of Portland in my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: The fishing industry is now the sixth largest primary industry in Australia and it employs over 25,000 people. It is estimated that the growth in fish consumption in Australia has risen from 6.2 kilograms per head in 1979-80 to something like 7 1/2 kilograms per head in 1984-85, and I suspect that it is probably growing further. Looking further at the industry and its structure and at the composition of our catch, we find that about 63 per cent of the value of Australian production comes from the lobster and prawn industries and about 18 per cent comes from pearl, abalone, scallops and oysters. About 19 per cent comes from fin fish but, with the growth in the orange roughy catch, I suspect that this percentage could be increasing.

The fishing industry is in some ways unique because if the harvest exceeds the rate of supply we will obviously over-exploit Australia's fishing fields, which could lead in the not too distant future to many areas being fished out. It is for this reason that sensible management practices obviously have to be followed. The Government is continuing to follow such practices. It will be interesting to see how successful they are. We hope that they are successful, of course, but it is important that those practices take account of the probability that a finite amount of fishing can be done without over-exploiting the industry.

One of the encouraging signs in the fishing industry is the growth in value added products. Some of the Japanese-type fish products are being utilised more and more, particularly in the export areas. I refer both to sashimi, sashimi being raw fish, which is very popular in Japan and is gaining some acceptance in Australia, and to surimi which is made from fish products being turned into other products such as crab sticks and the processing of different types of fish into a fish flesh type of food used in very tasty dishes. These have terrific value added potential and provide a great opportunity for us to increase our exports.

I said that I would talk a little about the orange roughy fields, which represent one of the most exciting developments in the Australian fishing industry and something that will add dramatically to our export income. The New Zealanders have been leading the way on the orange roughy. They are now processing something like 50,000 tonnes per annum, almost all of which is shipped to the United States of America, where the white flesh of the orange roughy is particularly well received. It is interesting to note that the acceptance of the orange roughy has even reached such hallowed halls as the television series Dallas. It was mentioned on one program a few months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not as good as barra, though. Barramundi is better.

—Yes; barramundi is very good too. I would like to say a little about the orange roughy because it represents a very interesting development. The fish have been in our area for a very long time but the fields were not discovered earlier because they are found at a very great depth. The fish have a reddish skin colour, hence the name orange roughy, and are typically about 30 centimetres long. The size of the fields in Australia is unknown because the fish is caught at such a great depth, but recently the fishing boats have made some fantastic catches. The Government, probably as an over-cautious measure, has decided to put a limit of 20,000 tonnes per annum on the allowable catch of orange roughy until research is undertaken to show the size of the fields.

SPEECH.PARA: Orange roughy tends to gather in large agglomerations or what is known in the local jargon as `hot spots'. These are often associated with undersea pinnacles but sometimes are on mud bottoms. They have been found off the west coast of Tasmania and around the south coast of mainland Australia. Some of the individual agglomerations are estimated to contain up to one million tonnes of fish. As I have said, the total volume is not fully known at this stage but it could be enormous. No one is sure what the sustainable yield is but the Government has been very cautious and set a 20,000 tonnes per annum limit on the catch.

The age of the fish is also unknown. It is quite possible that the average age of the fish being caught is 30 years. This could lead to a limit on the sustainable yield if it means that the fish do not reproduce rapidly. Although the maximum sustainable yield is unknown, it is quite reasonable to say that it could be of the order of 50,000 tonnes per annum or similar to that of New Zealand. It has certainly led to a rapid increase in the catch in southern Victoria, and I believe that it will lead to a dramatic increase in the value of fishing exports. As everyone is well aware, our balance of trade figures are nothing short of disastrous. Therefore, I question whether the Government is wise to increase the levies as rapidly as they will be increased if it leads to some curtailment of the growth of the industry. It is all very well to talk about the user pays principle, but there are many government services for which there is no charge to the user.

I reiterate that the Opposition does not oppose the Bills. We are very keen to see the fishing industry grow. We are particularly keen to see a growth in exports and a growth in value added products. Obviously, there is tremendous potential for this. Every bit of encouragement should be given to make sure that this potential is fully realised. The Opposition will be monitoring the performance of the management of fisheries. Obviously, we want to see fisheries develop to the point where they achieve the maximum sustainable yield. It is very important that the industry be encouraged to do that. We will be monitoring the performance of the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council to see that it functions as the legislation proposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fishing industry, with a total export value of about half a billion dollars, is a very important industry, especially in my electorate which has a long coastline. Honourable members opposite have raised concern about the additional powers bestowed upon fisheries inspectors. It is quite clear that they do have a potential to breach civil liberties, but I point out that the powers are no lesser powers than those enjoyed by many State fisheries and fauna authority people in this day. I do not think that there is any great evidence that their powers have been abused. I see no reason that we should fear abuse of these additional powers, although I believe that the situation should be monitored to make sure that abuse does not occur.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the remarks of the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) about necessary research funds. I believe that this was also mentioned by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). It is absolutely essential to get commercial objectivity into the application of any research funds. To a large extent, it is beholden on this industry to do so. The industry has representation on the new board and I am sure that the new board will be much more aware of that than perhaps has been the case in the past.
