For instance, although the crown-of-thorns starfish pose a problem to the Great Barrier Reef, the issue was not really germane to the fishing industry and perhaps it was inappropriate that fishing industry research funds were used in crown-of-thorns studies. I hope that that will not occur in the future and that we will see much more commercial objectivity in the application of those funds.

Honourable members opposite lamented the additional cost recovery which the Government seeks. I seem to be forever explaining to honourable members opposite how the free enterprise system works. Very few of them seem to have a grasp of it. It would seem to me that, if the industry were called upon to fund a greater percentage of the costs incurred, it would be bound to take greater notice of how that money was spent. It seems self-evident that if we are to get efficiencies in industry, industry must bear the cost involved. In 1987-88, $30.1m has been allocated for fisheries management and development programs. That is an increase of $8.8m. This has been funded to a very large extent by new levies-for instance, $3.5m for new fisheries management initiatives; $2.5m for Torres Strait capital items; $1m for the northern prawn fishery adjustment scheme, and $1.8m for fisheries research. I rather suspect that the levy of $295 per annum on fishing boats was simply the sum required to make up the balance. I would say that that is how that figure came about and that answers the question raised by honourable members opposite.

Previous speakers have alluded to the need for value adding. I think that value adding is essential for Australia in every form of export. There have been some advances in value adding in the fishing industry. Sashimi, southern blue- fin tuna, is a great example of this. It is through the initiative of sashimi that the industry has been sustained in Esperance. When all the licences were bought up by South Australia, there was not enough left there to be of commercial value without adopting sashimi practices, and that has been very successful. There is another value added process which I think needs a lot of credit, and that is the process of smoked tuna. A company in Esperance produces smoked tuna which is a very good product. In my view, it rivals salmon. I think that we should see it on the parliamentary dining room menu. It is also cheaper than salmon, which should be an attraction to the Parliament.

The crayfish industry, too, uses the value added principle. I remember some years ago watching developments in the hydraulic pressing of crayfish heads and other body parts to extract meat which is turned into pastes, pates and other products for the catering trade. Traditionally there has been about a 30 per cent recovery of meat from fish-that is, the white fish fillet market. That means that a substantial amount of the meat is obviously being wasted. This cannot be allowed to continue. There are processes available to recover a lot of this meat. I am glad to say that there is evidence that some people are now looking to recover this meat for the making of pates, pastes and fillers for general cooking. That is also to be applauded.

Other initiatives need to be taken in fisheries research. It is my view that not enough work has been done. I remember advocating many years ago that the fisheries research industry purchase the remote-controlled underwater vehicles that were available in Australia, as I had seen these vehicles operate. They are extremely good. They show the bottom of the ocean with great clarity and would be an invaluable tool in fisheries development. For instance, in my electorate there is now a conflict between the prawn trawlers off the coast of Broome and the $40m a year pearl fishery. Obviously, we cannot put the pearl industry at risk, but it is equally important that we cannot, and should not, stop a prawn fishery if it does not in any way impinge upon the viability of the pearl fishery. It would seem to me that the argument hinges on whether pearl shell is present in these waters. Pearl fishermen tell me that it is, although they have not tried to exploit it. The prawn trawlermen tell me that it is not. A viewing of this area of the ocean by a remote-controlled underwater vehicle and its very sensitive camera would determine this very quickly, one way or the other. It is a tool that should be used. Also, it should be used to seek out additional crayfish grounds which are thought to exist west into the Indian Ocean.

Mullet, which is probably a much despised fish, is used by many people as cray bait. It is a very cheap fish. When one tastes it, one can understand why. Unfortunately, this reputation of mullet has affected the reputation of Shark Bay mullet, which is a very different fish. It is a larger fish and lacks the somewhat muddy taste of ordinary mullet. I find it one of the best eating fish of all. I hope that although this mullet is of the same species as ordinary mullet-it is marketed as Shark Bay mullet-it will find a better market and greater market acceptability. It is a fish that abounds in the very fertile waters of Shark Bay. It could be exploited to the benefit of fishermen and, in fact, the whole industry.

I am pleased to note that the per capita consumption of fish in Australia has gone up. It is now about seven kilograms a head per annum. I believe that it has much more potential. Consumption can grow by quite a degree. Of course, that means that fisheries research must be kept up. We have to find new species and new fields to make sure that the stock is not depleted. I believe that there is some evidence to suggest that the fisheries industry in my State of Western Australia is probably the best managed fishery in the country. The joint operations between the Western Australian Government and the Federal Government appear to be working very well. The industry in Western Australia could possibly serve as a model for the rest of Australia.

The other thing that concerns me in fisheries research is sport fishermen, because sport fishing is a very popular hobby. I get continual complaints from sport fishermen that the allowing of commercial fishing operations too close to shore is detracting from catches and is generally making the much sought after holiday less enjoyable because fish catches have dropped. I do not know how much substance there is in the complaints, but the complaints are so consistent that I suspect that there is some substance to them. When commercial operators operate too close to shore or to popular sport fishing spots, it is quite likely that there is a reduction in numbers.

I believe that we could well use some of the research money for the establishment of artificial reefs and submerged floating platforms to attract the middle swimming range of fish. Artificial reefs, I believe, can be easily constructed by obtaining old Hallpac tyres, filling the bottom half with concrete, drilling holes in the top, tying them together and sinking them. In some places where this has been done on a small scale, it has certainly attracted fish. It has provided habitats which, there is absolutely no doubt, have increased the number of fish in the area. One has only to look at the North Rankin platform and the fish that abound there that were not there before this habitat was artificially provided. There are many areas of the ocean which are now barren which I believe could be stocked or improved if artificial habitats were provided. I believe that this would help to break down any potential conflict between sport fishermen and commercial fishermen.

This legislation deserves to be commended. I am pleased that the Opposition is supporting it. Indeed, I fail to see how it could do otherwise. I think it expresses this Government's ongoing concern for the industry. I believe that, with the concern shown by this Government for all areas of fishing, the fishing industry will go from strength to strength.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) has said, the Opposition supports the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill, the Fishing Industry Research Amendment Bill and the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill. I think he might agree with me that there is frequently support between the parties but, unfortunately, that is seldom mentioned in the Press. It usually wishes only to report those issues on which we disagree. However, the honourable member also raised the issue of cost recovery. He said that in some way we on this side of the House needed to know how the free enterprise system worked. I assure him that we know how the free enterprise system works. Free enterprise, of course, does not work on the principle that one is forced to pay a levy or a charge when one has no input to the cost structure. In this regard the Opposition, on behalf of many industries-be they the meat industry, the fruit industry or the fishing industry-objects to a government which continually says that there must be more cost recovery and that there must be more of the user pays concept. The theory is excellent. The problem from which the fishing industry, for instance, suffers is simply that it cannot in any way control those costs.

SPEECH.PARA: There is probably no better example of a free enterprise industry and a small business industry than the fishing industry, although these days there are huge costs involved with equipment. But the fishing industry has always been very much about small operators operating a single boat of whatever size. Of course, over the years they have achieved wonderful efficiencies in their operations. When they are told that a charge, which is presently levied at 44 per cent of what the Government deems to be a reasonable charge to operate the system, is to rise to 60 per cent, in the following year to 75 per cent, and the year after that to 90 per cent, they see the cost rising to such a rate that, on average, boat operators will have to pay a licence fee in Commonwealth fishing areas as high as $3,000. It has been increased from $1,500 to $3,000. One can see why they are pretty concerned. Their complaint is not that they have to contribute; their complaint is that there is no way that they can deal with the efficiencies or make recommendations of any note as to how the service should be provided.

It is just as I said the other day on a matter relating to health. The great difference between the Opposition and the Government on all these issues is this: we frequently have the same objective-in this case it is to control and advance the welfare of the fishing industry-but often we have an entirely different direction in reaching that objective. We do not believe that it is always necessary to own the shop to deliver the service. In fact, the people are often best served if a government chooses to get others to do the particular work and pays them for it-in other words, if it subcontracts out wherever possible. That raises the next point in all this, and that is that some of this legislation proposes the construction of a new fisheries research vessel, which I understand could be as expensive as $20m, of which some $6m is available out of the fishing research fund.

There again, fisheries research is being carried out at this very moment using a private enterprise boat. One must wonder just what we shall achieve by buying a boat. To start with, they are not inexpensive things to move from one place to another. Of course, one does not necessarily have to give a long term charter to a particular company. Admittedly, certain equipment would need to be on board, but otherwise one can frequently hire a boat in one area when one needs it to do a particular research project, and then hire another one in another area, without shifting them the length and breadth of the Australian coastline. There seem to me to be substantial reasons why certain contractual arrangements for the hiring of boats would be satisfactory, and I am sure that researchers' needs could be met in that way, even though it might represent a small amount of inconvenience. Of course, the amount of inconvenience that we are talking about for the taxpayer of Australia is $20m of government expenditure, when that sum could be directly applied to research through the hiring of other people's equipment and leaving them with all the worries and concerns of its general operation.

I know that after my making these remarks someone will probably rise to say, `Oh, but when you work out the cost, it is substantially cheaper'. I do not always recognise that that is a fact. The reality is that figures will always be produced to prove that point, but all successful business operators generally avoid getting into businesses in which they are not expert. The Commonwealth Government, of any political colour, is expert in very few. It is becoming more and more noticeable today how the private sector, if it is in the business of selling groceries, sells groceries. It does not build shopping centres. It gives that job to an expert. It is quite happy to pay the rent that the expert requires, because it has learnt over time that that is cheaper, and that it maximises its profits by keeping its capital to do the thing that it does best. In this case, the community capital is needed to undertake research, not to run a research vessel. I am sure that over a period we would have more money for research were we not to build the boat. Nevertheless, they are my personal remarks. The Opposition is not opposing the Government's determination in this area, although I believe that the industry is somewhat concerned about this problem.

There are other matters on which I should like to comment. Remarks have been made by previous speakers regarding the powers that are being given to Commonwealth inspectors in this legislation. I have no objection to that. I am one who would support the concept of human rights, but I am also pragmatic enough, having lived in fishing districts for most of my mature life, and representing a number now as a member of parliament, to realise that it is just pointless thinking that a fisheries inspection vessel could come alongside another boat, take note of things that are believed to represent breaches of the legislation needed to protect the fishery, and then duck back into the nearest town where there was a magistrate and get a warrant. That is clearly not practical. To my knowledge it has never applied to State inspectors, and nor should it apply in this area.

We are talking about protecting an asset. Western Australia has taken the lead in limited entry fisheries and strict controls on size and the other things that go with that. I am not one who would normally stand for controls past any reasonable degree, and yet in the case of fishing I see the absolute need for those sorts of controls, and I accept that only government can provide them. Limited entry to a fishery is the best means by which one can control somewhat the exploitation of the area. Unlike any other form of farming, of course, we do not plant the crops and we do not allocate the grounds. We can only rely on nature to rebuild the schools of fish. If the resource is over-exploited, we do not get the necessary recovery. We have seen that in other areas, particularly the southern bluefin area, which I was representing until the last redistribution.

So, those powers are needed, on sea and on land. It has been noticeable that since sensible arrangements have been in place, the industry has been better off. So, we see that there is a need. I have not heard of too many examples where people have complained about their treatment in that regard. Some of the penalties today are very harsh on those who choose to break the rules. There was a notable case in Western Australia just recently. I think that people must recognise that if they want to break those sorts of rules and put a whole fishery at risk, they will have to pay a substantial penalty.

Mention has also been made of innovation in the fishing industry, and that is worthy of a comment in this debate, particularly the move in my electorate towards sending away live crayfish to certain markets, and how successful that has been. It is a peculiar approach to value added, because in truth we send away the whole fish and probably do less to it here in Australia. But it is substantially valuable to the nation because it improves the financial return on the product. As I have mentioned in this place previously, the exploitation of live crayfish-or lobster; however people choose to name them today-relies heavily on the availability of air freight and good connections. That has been a problem, particularly for Geraldton in my electorate, although I have not heard the level of complaint about it in recent times, and I assume-taking the normal rule on that-that if there is no complaint, things must be operating reasonably satisfactorily. No doubt the moment they do not, I shall be informed again.

Other speakers have mentioned the Japanese sashimi market. That is clearly the area in which there is a high grade return on a product as compared with turning it into cat food. I have always thought that it was a great pity that we are prepared to use such a huge amount of our fish resources as pet food. It seems to me that a large amount of it should be reserved for human consumption. I have seen wonderful edible fish resources caught by certain fishermen by means which made them suitable only for cray bait because they were worth more as cray bait than they were for human consumption. The salmon industry in the south of Western Australia at one stage was allowed to sell only the heads as cray bait, but the heads were getting longer than the body as they were sawn off because of the returns that could be got.

We are now reading of aquaculture, in which fish are being bred at sea in pens. Such developments are a matter of great opportunity, particularly as we are introducing Northern Hemisphere-type fish, which are in huge demand-Atlantic salmon and fish of that nature. That is a wonderful opportunity. It is amazing to think that the common trout can be encouraged, apparently, to grow to three times the size that they generally grow to in fresh water if introduced to a salt-water environment. This is just another area of that. Nevertheless, I note that some of these developments with huge capital investment are concerned about the recovery of seal flocks and things of that nature. Seals are breaking into the pens. No doubt that will be a problem for the government of the day in the future, as the conservationists come in with their arguments about who should survive on this planet-human beings or those animals. They will create difficulties, just as the kangaroo does for people trying to generate an income from growing sheep and cattle. I am one for a balance in all these things but I am also in favour of maintaining a standard of living for the people of Australia. At this time with all the problems we have with international indebtedness, it is absolutely essential that we maximise every opportunity we have to create export products.

I would like to raise a matter related to the fishing industry in general which is specific to my own electorate. It comes back to the cost that governments impose upon the fishing industry or any other industry when, if you like, Mr Deputy Speaker, it tries too hard. I refer to the marina that has been established in Dongara which is in my electorate. The area is a major source of crayfish and the town is extremely popular with professional fishermen during the white crayfish season which is a short period after the crayfish moult when they can be caught in very large numbers. It is a time of the year when the catching potential centres on Dongara. At that time of the year the Dongara marina can be overcrowded. A solution proposed by the Department of Marine and Harbours was to establish a lot of pens so that the boats, instead of having to anchor freely within the marina, would run in between piles and pens thereby increasing the number of boats that could be put within the marina. That is fine, but the problem is again that no one is to be told how much that might cost. The fishing industry is not convinced that when the piles and pens are introduced it will necessarily improve the number of boats that can be contained within the marina.

The Western Australian coast is very open. There are no natural bays or river mouths of any note. A stone wall has to be built out into the ocean or to a reef to enable the boats to shelter. That is a very successful arrangement but along came the Department of Marine and Harbours offering this great improvement. To their credit, the fishermen fought it bitterly. I support their position. They point out that there are only a few weeks of the year when the harbour is overcrowded but that the fishermen, as permanent residents, would be the ones obliged to rent the pens which would cost them thousands of dollars a year. They do not need that loss to their revenue. At this stage of the game there is really no reason to spend taxpayers' money on this particular development. I hope that consequently the State departmental people have decided that this is no longer a sensible development. I hope that they will not proceed with that development, certainly in the short term or until such time as the fishing industry itself indicates that it thinks the investment by government is worthwhile and therefore is prepared to meet the cost of hiring those pens from the Government. It is amazing how quickly these things get expensive. The small marina at Dongara now requires the employment of a harbour-master. All the costs grow. Having a harbour-master, whose sole responsibility seems to be seeing to it that nobody stays at the jetty too long, is a pretty expensive way of organising the marina. Knowing my fishermen friends from that area, they would have very simple means of getting someone away from the jetty if he stayed there too long and somebody else was waiting. I would not like to be around when words were exchanged or whatever else was exchanged. At times we offer too much and then, of course, we seek to charge for it. Although that is not wrong it comes back to the original argument of striking these levies against people when they do not need them to be imposed.

In closing, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie praised the idea of rubber-tyre reefs. I agree with him entirely. I would like him to know that many years ago when I was president of the Carnarvon Shire, part of his electorate, we commenced installing rubber-tyre reefs. Because we were using small tyres we had trouble keeping them on the seabed. The main reason for that was that the fisheries people would not let us put the tyre reefs in protected waters. That seemed a little silly because most amateur fishermen do not want to go out into very rough waters to try to catch a few fish. There is no doubt that they work once that protection is there. One has to look only at the huge stacks of worn-out tyres around the place to be reminded of the fact that a lot of the Australian coastline does not harbour fish because it does not have a reef system or some other system. We know what happens when a tyre reef is built. Skin-divers are quick to tell us about the profusion of fish around any sunken vessel. It is a great way of getting rid of a problem: tyres otherwise have to be burned which pollutes the atmosphere. We can use the rubber tyres to build reefs in appropriate places to improve the quantity of fish that we have in our waters and all that goes with that. It offers a wonderful recreation for Australians to get out and catch a few fish to supplement their diet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be common agreement within this Parliament, and I think in the informed community outside, that the Australian fishing industry is undergoing a period of significant change. I am pleased to be a member of a government that has played a very important part and a very positive role in this period. This Government has embarked upon a proper management strategy for our fisheries. It proposes to establish the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council and, in doing so, it will establish a very important forum for the Government and industry to get together to talk through the problems that have prevailed. The Government has also worked very hard to develop a consultative and co-operative approach, not only with industry but also with the States. This has to be acknowledged as a major win because too often we have a Commonwealth-State conflict instead of Commonwealth-State agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has taken what I would see as a specialist approach as well as a broad industry approach in that it has given special acknowledgment to the need to develop management plans for all aspects and the specific aspects of the industry. The Government has targeted the major fisheries such as the northern prawn fishery, the tuna fishery, the south-east trawl, the southern shark fishery and other areas it believes are important as individual sectors of the industry. The Government has also been successful in achieving legal arrangements for fishery management within the off-shore constitutional settlement with, I think, all but two States. That is not because of political reasons because I note that Queensland has given a lead here. There has been an agreement in place with Queensland for almost two years. The Government has achieved so much. Its greatest achievement has been in the acknowledgment of the special needs for money to be put into research and development in the fishing industry.

Over a long time a lot of money has been spent by the previous Federal Government and this Government to develop this very important rural industry. I read some figures the other day which showed that the fishing industry was now rated as the fifth, I think, most important rural industry in Australia. In 1986-87, the gross value of production reached $639m. That is an enormous amount of money. The national catch was 152,500 tonnes. We are talking about a huge industry, a vital export industry, an industry which, from an export point of view alone, last year was worth $591m. That has almost doubled since 1981. I believe that some people can take great pride in what has happened at the State level, at the industry level and at the Commonwealth Government level, for we have seen the development of what was a very small industry, one having great difficulties. It is now growing and coming through with great success.

There are more than 9,000 boats in the Australian commercial fishing fleet. There are some 21,000 people employed in the harvesting of sea resources. There are almost 5,000 people involved in the processing area. We can add to that all the ancillary backup staff in the transportation, clerical and administration areas. It is a very big industry. It is saving our nation hundreds of millions of dollars in imports as well as earning hundreds of millions of dollars in exports. We all agree-this is obvious from the bipartisan support for the legislation-that the industry has enormous potential in both the export and domestic markets.

I think the industry is at a crossroads. I note that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in his second reading speech talked about it being a rural industry. He stressed what the Government had done in many of these areas. I am wondering whether we are treating it as a rural industry. For all that is taking place, I question whether we are winning the war. I do not mean to take an analogous approach of there being a war. If one makes comparisons of what has actually taken place with our exports, we see that our exports jumped from $230m in 1980-81 to $591m in 1986-87. That is praiseworthy. We say `Congratulations' to everybody who is involved. If we look at the imports of fish products during the same period, we find that in 1980-81 our imports were $190m, but last year that figure had skyrocketed to $421m.

So we are at the crossroads. We see that more money is being spent. In fact, since 1969 some $28.5m has been spent on research and development. Exceptional recognition has been given by this Government and by the States. There has been a willingness to bring about a management strategy for our fisheries to protect what we have. There has been dialogue, consultation and a co-operative approach, yet I am not sure that we are winning. When we look at those figures and at what is taking place we see that imports are still outstripping our exports. This must worry many people in the industry. Clearly we are not addressing the needs and demands of the domestic market. For if we were, then there would not be this propensity to import these products. Or is it because our prices on the domestic market are not as competitive with what we get on the export market? I do not know; but I do know that the import figures continue to blow out.

I give full credit to the Government for what it is doing and for the establishment in this legislation of a Fishing Industry Research and Development Council. I give full credit to the Government and the Minister for the very positive role that they are taking in preparing five-year plans for fisheries research and development. I give them credit also for ensuring that there will be representatives on this Council who have fishing experience. One comment made by the Minister-I took it to mind-was that there `shall be a mix of skills and abilities'. Surely this is commendable. We have a new approach that is working and we have consultation and co-operation. Our exports are increasing but, clearly, we are still not competing with our imports. I note that the Fishing Industry Research Act, in its research and development, will allow the Government not only to consider the research and development of our fisheries, but also to look hard at fishermen and businesses.

I welcome what the Government has done. I note that the Minister only recently announced the opening of a new area between Sydney and Cape York that will be an explanatory region. I question whether or not we are still doing enough for fishermen. I spoke to two fishermen in the last 24 hours and I said, `What is the greatest problem that you have?'. Both these fellows said, `Money'. One fellow said to me, `Look, we are a rural industry. We are in all the reports as rural industries, but we do not have the same rights as any other ``farmer''. We do not have access to the money that any other ``farmer'' has. We do not have access to the rural reconstruction funds and the rural adjustment schemes that the other ``farmers'' have'. We might put `farmers' in inverted commas because I do not think all fishermen like to see themselves as farmers. They are, in fact, harvesting a product, yet they do not have that access. It is understandable. What bank wants to lend $250,000 to a fisherman? If the bank lends to a farmer or grazier the land will not sink, but a boat can. There are not the same risks involved. Yet it has been very clear in what the Minister and others have said in this chamber that this industry has enormous potential, but we need to develop that potential amongst the fishermen themselves; we need to make finance available to the fishermen; and we need to come up with some sort of insurance scheme to protect them.

The other point that was raised with me was that the cost of insurance to fishermen is simply so high that it is almost impossible to meet that commitment. So, too, is the cost of upgrading equipment. When there is a need to upgrade the facilities and equipment, the cost is just enormous.

Whilst I am very commendatory in my remarks, I urge that a review take place of the assistance that is actually given to fishermen. As research and development is now allowed within this Act, and revamping will take place, I urge that everything be done to ensure that we sit down and talk with the fishermen to find out what their needs are. One fellow suggested to me that there should be a fishermen's bank. We have always talked about small business banks, rural banks and so on. I am not sure that that is the answer. I do believe that fishermen have to have access to low cost money; they have to have some sort of insurance package deal; and they have to have special assistance when it comes to management skills because they are dealing with businesses worth hundreds of thousands of dollars. We seem to take note of the needs of the small business fellow in the strip shopping area or the supermarket area, but I do not think we have given due cognisance to the needs of these particular businessmen, and that is what they are. As I said, there are some 9,000 boats which are worth many millions of dollars. It is an important industry earning hundreds of millions of dollars for our nation with the potential to replace hundreds of millions of dollars in imports. If we are to address what I see as a continuing problem, then we need to come to grips with the specific needs of fishermen. I support the legislation before the chamber. I welcome the initiatives of the Minister and the Government, but I ask that this be one specific area of investigation when the new Council is set up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill, the Fishing Industry Research Amendment Bill and the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill. The Opposition supports these Bills because they involve two things: first, a recognition of what the fishing industry has meant to Australia and what it can mean in the future; and secondly, a recognition that in order to achieve the great potential of the fishing industry a system of research and development has to be fostered in this country if we are to get any industry to realise its potential. A recent report indicated that, on the scope of research and development funds available throughout the world to industries, Australia did not rank well. The report also observed that in research and development private industry commitment was very much lower than the public research and development commitment of governments and, again, in comparison to the rest of the world that was not a good indication either. We also find that Australia has the capacity to develop and research as is indicated by papers which say that while Australians present 2 per cent of the papers believed in scientific circles around the world, only 0.8 per cent of the patents throughout the world are attributed to Australians. So there is a gap in the recognition factor also.

SPEECH.PARA: Any legislation that encourages the development and research of Australia's fishing industries can only be welcomed in this country. As I said, it is certainly welcomed by the Opposition. It can change a depleting resource into a vibrant and expanded major industry and assist in our trading prospects, particularly within the Pacific rim. The lack of knowledge of the sea in relation to mariculture and the fishing industry in general is enormous in comparison with the extensive knowledge that Australians possess regarding agriculture and other land-based industries.

As we are approaching our Bicentenary, it is very interesting to note the enormous changes to, and development of, our land since 1788. However, in comparison with Australia's landscape, Captain Cook could quite well feel at home with our present seascape even though 200 years have passed since he sailed through these waters. That is how little we have done in development of our off-shore resources.

Until recently it was said that if one required up to date information on our reef and fishing grounds the best maps and information were available from Taiwan, Japan, Korea or Indonesia-anywhere but Australia. This is significant to the extent that all these countries have been granted fishing rights within Australia and apparently know those areas they are fishing better than we do ourselves. This is, of course, a sad reflection on the resources given to mapping our major fishing grounds and the seas around Australia.

The purpose of the legislation before the House is to improve the administrative system of the fishing industry and to provide for the funding, research and development of the industry. The Government's policy will be similar to the legislative guidelines set out for rural industries research. Although this legislation does not refer specifically to mariculture, it is this area of research on which Australia's concentration of effort should be centred. The Australian Institute of Marine Science outside Townsville is presently engaged in research under the directorship of Dr Baker. The threat of the crown-of-thorns starfish has already been mentioned, and it is this institute, not the fishing industry, that is doing such research. The research shows that the knowledge that can be gained from the oceans is incredibly important. Examining the coral core from the Great Barrier Reef can help provide a better understanding of our climate. Artificial reefs can become a rich source of fish and crustaceans. Building materials can be supplied from the sea and fish farms can be established off and on shore. It is these factors that we are only just beginning to research and consider seriously.

Dr Joe Baker mentioned the major plus that Australia has, and that is its largely unexplored area, rich in natural species, largely unaffected by intensive occupancy and not yet subject to human manipulation and dominance. He also said:

In the most recent studies we have seen the level of pollutants determined in marine species within the Great Barrier Reef region, to be at a lower level than those which are accepted for safety standards throughout the world. In that way we are indeed in an advantaged position compared with other countries.

When one thinks of the protection given to our native flora and fauna, the lack of concern when it comes to the marine environment is simply amazing. In the course of this debate we have heard of such problems as the taking of undersized fish, the waste within the trawling industry and the use of our precious fish for fishmeal instead of products suitable for the table. We have corrupted the system to a large extent, yet we still lack this protective concern.

Australia is years behind many other countries in the intensely competitive mariculture area. Earlier this year, I went to Taiwan with my wife, and we had occasion to visit a major research facility practising mariculture. It was interesting to know how long that had been established and the type of experience and research that it was giving to its industry in Taiwan. These people are looking towards Australia as a potential area for what they are doing in research. They are adapting their expertise to our climatic conditions yet there are difficulties in transferring that technology. One is that we do not recognise Taiwan, another is that visas are difficult to get, and thirdly, if it comes to a matter of rapid transportation to Taiwan as a market, we are left in some doubt as to whether we can make shipments as rapidly as we would like. In Japan, research is so advanced that the Japanese are already planning to build massive marine cities. The development of the Four Seasons-Barrier Reef Hotel and the Wonderland Aquarium, both in the Townsville region, are signs that Australia has the ability to compete with other countries and is prepared to adopt the necessary technology. However, this type of technology would not have been foreseen until recently, let alone catered for in legislation.

In a developed country like Australia, which possesses a high level of knowledge and expertise, there is no excuse for our present backward position. Australia could be a major leader in producing and exporting the products of mariculture, given the correct encouragement and incentive. The legislation before us has been developed since 1979, when the then Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce began a major inquiry into the Australian fishing industry. The Fishing Industry Research Act 1969 will be replaced by this legislation. This will ensure that we remain up to date with the modern technology of the fishing industry. The aim of the legislation is to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of fisheries research through the establishment of the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council, which will provide annual research and development programs, approve payments from the trust fund and monitor and report on projects funded by the trust fund. The research committee will produce a five-year plan for research and development and annual operational programs. The Council will consist of a chairman, government member and between three and seven other members.

The Fishing Industry Research and Development Trust Fund will consist of funds from approved State research funds and will be matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth Government to a maximum of one per cent of the gross value of industry production.

The introduction of this legislation should bring about a whole change in Australia's attitude to the sea. We should be looking to the sea for the potential in farming it, as we farm the land. It is only in recent years that Australia has been involved in any major research involving the improvement of marine species. It is the policies that we implement now that will affect the development and future of our marine environment. We have vast areas of land that have not been touched by man lying dormant under the sea. The implications of farming that land should be seriously considered if we are to ensure the best possible management, in the long term, of our marine environment. We have an Australian fishing zone and therefore we are responsible for that area of sea. That area is far greater than our mass of land-8.6 million versus 7.6 million square kilometres. That factor is not generally recognised by the 16 million Australians. The legislation will strengthen the powers of fishery inspectors under three existing acts-the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968, the Fisheries Act 1952 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984.

I agree with the sentiments that have been expressed that we must give powers to the fishing inspectors if they are to do their policing properly and make the necessary apprehensions. This has to be done immediately and cannot be delayed, as that is the only type of restraint that will be recognised by the offenders. Provision is also made for more stringent laws regarding undersized fish catches. I would like to mention here that there needs to be some co-ordination between the States as far as fish catches and weights are concerned. It is known that while some fish and crustaceans are available at a certain size in Queensland, when one goes over the border to New South Wales, undersized crustaceans can be sold there. In other places, protection is given to some fish but not to others. For example, in Queensland there is a closed season for barramundi, but I understand that there is not one in the Northern Territory. Of course, fish do not know the difference between borders, and should they roam over one area instead of another, they might suffer the fate of being apprehended on the end of a fish hook. These measures will ensure better protection of Australia's fishing zone by enabling officers to exercise powers of stopping, entering and searching a vessel without a warrant, if they have reasonable grounds upon which to act. The surplus funds from the existing Fishing Industry Research and Development Trust Fund will be spent on the purchase of a new fisheries research ship for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Division of Fisheries Research. At present, the CSIRO leases such a vessel, the Soela. This vessel will be a great asset in assisting in the research of this invaluable industry.

What we have learnt from farming our land should result in a more efficient and effective farming of our marine resources. Only last month, the Government announced plans to open up a large stretch of Australia's eastern seaboard to managed fish trawling. It is up to the Government to ensure the proper management of this region. We must give the Government credit for opening up that region. This is essential if Australia's fishing industry is to continue its successful expansion. However, the Government's record to date, and probably that of all governments, in the management of the fishing industry has been poor. As Dr Baker has said, the Government has not shown the:

. . . willingness to analyse areas of country which are particularly well suited to different types of marine development but rather allowed a comparatively haphazard establishment of coastal farms without consideration of desirable features which would optimise the chance of success of these new ventures.

Already the fishing industry has complained about the Government's lack of consultation concerning this legislation. We can only hope the introduction of this legislation will bring about a change in the Government's attitude. The Government could be saving large sums of money if it used technology to its greatest advantage. This is the main reason why this legislation has had to be introduced in the first place-to keep pace with the modern technology of today. Remote sensing technology saved more than $20m in costs by allowing the mapping of the Great Barrier Reef region in the shortest possible time. Greater awareness of this type of technology will be of vital assistance as we exploit our seas and preserve them for the future. The legislation will enable greater emphasis to be placed on education and the wise management of our seas.

Mr Stephen Midgely, a fresh water fisheries consultant in Queensland, has expressed grave fears over the survival of our more popular fish species. Mr Midgely believes there is a necessity to establish fish farms, not only to ensure the long-term preservation of fish species but also to produce a reliable number of fish species as food items.

The structural framework that this legislation implements will ensure the greatest potential for research into finding a long-term solution to the depletion of our marine species and administering that solution. Northern Australia relies on fish such as the barramundi for market success and, particularly, the tourist dollar. As the influx of tourists increase in the north, these fish are rapidly depleting. Queensland's barramundi ban comes into force in November and will continue until 1 February next year. This has been introduced to protect the fish from exploitation. Barramundi are subject to capture because this is the time of the spawning migration from rivers to the coastal foreshores. This ban applies to both recreational and commercial fishermen. However, placing fishing bans will not be an answer to the long-term problem of the depletion of our marine life. This is all the more reason for the fast and efficient implementation of this legislation, because damage is often caused to fisheries by ignorance.

Nursery areas for some fish species can be destroyed by the draining and filling of swamp areas and the destruction of mangrove systems and through the over-trawling of some fishing areas. The construction of dams and weirs across the lower reaches of some streams can also cause serious effects on fish such as the barramundi, as they can severely limit the area available for fish to mature. This destruction is often carried out without the authorities being aware of the detrimental effects upon marine life.

At present, it is inevitable that pollution will increase as the tourist industry booms. The effect of pollution on fish is obviously serious and, unfortunately, not adequately understood. If the decline of fisheries is not understood properly, then the Government, which is responsible through its policies to protect those fisheries, could, through ignorance, make ill-judged or wrong decisions. Hopefully, with the passing of this legislation, such knowledge will increase. With this legislation in place, the long-term prospects of success for a marine farming industry in Australia is great.

Western Australia has already moved to establish marine parks with integrated land-sea management conditions. In the Northern Territory and Queensland, small industries have been established in the farming of prawns and barramundi. Flying Fish Point and Mourilyan Harbour near Innisfail produce prawn and barramundi spawn for sale to commercial farms. A certain number of spawn from prawns is released into the open sea every month, and the Government is releasing barramundi spawn into its old habitats such as the Burdekin River. The success of mariculture industries will be determined by the close collaboration between the Government, researchers and the industry.

It is inevitable in any new farming industry that problems will arise. That is why it is vital that this close link among these three groups is maintained to solve these problems and move together to enhance a great future in mariculture and fishing. It is up to this Government and all governments-including State governments-to ensure that the mariculture industry is characterised by wise planning and development, but this must be balanced with a minimum amount of red tape and regulation. The passing of this legislation represents a step in closing the gap in our knowledge of our seascape and, hopefully, it will lead the way to developing Australia's great potential in the mariculture industry. Dr Joe Baker and the Australian Institute of Marine Science have already established a beach head. It is up to governments, and the industry-land and sea based-to develop that beach head for the benefit of future generations of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robinson The Hon I.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fishing industry is one of our most significant industries in Australia today. It is significant because its development has brought about a vast change in the economy of the industry, the economy of the individual fishermen, the economy of the industry overall and in its capacity to supply the domestic market. As a consequence of the expansion of fishing agreements that have been created recently, the industry is a significant contributor to our export market and our export earnings. Basically, the Bill deals with research and development and it is in those two fields that much has yet to be accomplished.

SPEECH.PARA: In the research field, the fishermen themselves, and I am sure most Australians, recognise that we still know too little about the problems of the fishing industry and problems associated with some of the worrying diseases that can occur. In particular I refer to the red spot disease problem along the northern rivers of New South Wales, in southern Queensland and in other locations around Australia. The problem with the red spot disease is predominant in the Clarence River in my electorate. I believe that thus far inadequate research has been carried out into this serious problem. There is a lack of real knowledge about the cause of this disease and the remedial action that may or may not be taken in respect of the control of the river systems and the matter that may enter our river systems. Much has yet to be learnt about this one serious imposition on our fishing industry. So I welcome the expansion of research as envisaged under this legislation and, for that matter, the restructuring of the administration for research.

I hope that the new committee will see fit to ensure that funding is directed to important fields such as the one I referred to, and there are many others. Priorities need to be established to ensure that funding is available to those areas which, on serious consideration by the committee and following advice from technical experts, are seen to have real needs in the first instance for the expenditure of funds raised from the industry and supplemented by the taxpayer. The taxpayer contribution to research for the fishing industry is substantial, and we want to ensure that it is spent wisely and effectively. So I repeat: The proposed new committee will have a great responsibility in this regard. In fact, you, Mr Deputy Speaker, as the member for Wide Bay, mentioned to me earlier today a matter of some significance when you referred to a recent report about Japanese interests involved in fishing using satellites to oversight and locate certain ocean currents which give them a precise fix on the location of huge volumes of fish. Of course, the consequence of that is for fishing to be directed to those particular zones and perhaps that will result in overfishing. Perhaps it also means that, while there is a certain degree of research in an approach of that kind, there are also dangers.

The real problem that the fishing industry has recognised in recent years is that we still know too little about the effect of the catches in various fishing grounds around our continent and in the waters that Australians wish to fish commercially. Likewise, in our rivers and estuaries there is a great deal of concern about whether there should be closures, whether there has been overfishing or whether there are other reasons for what are believed to be difficulties that are encountered by professional fishermen and others who are concerned with the future availability of fish species for recreational and commercial fishing. The answers are not easily gained and wide research is required in many directions. If we think about the prawn industry in particular, the recent advent of prawn farming has brought a whole new concept to this section of the fishing industry. Reference by other members to the advent of fresh water marron is another example of the new fields about which we still know too little. We must not take risks in advancing the industry-and perhaps it has been too quick in some directions-and we must encourage those who are prepared to invest substantial sums of money in it.

Millions of dollars are being directed to specific prawn farming projects. We need to match that spending with adequate research and technical surveillance so that we know just what is being done and what the ultimate outcome will be. The concern of the ordinary fishermen, those who toil long hours in difficult conditions facing the rigours of the weather and the commercial result, is the increasing levies which they will face. The Budget a few weeks ago imposed a brand new levy of $259 for the relicensing of existing fishing boats. Not a lot of information was given about it except that it will raise about $1.8m. Let us assume that it will be the responsibility of the new committee to decide where some of this very substantial sum of levy raising will be directed. Another Budget proposal increased amounts raised under the existing levy provisions. These measures put in the hands of those responsible a very substantial sum of money to be expended in the interests of the fishing industry and of Australia.

The industry is continuing to say very loudly that it wants more self-management. It is concerned about some of the decisions that flow from the respective Federal and State fisheries departments. Of course there is an important link between the Federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy-I am glad to see the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) in the House at the moment; he will be aware of the relationship-and the New South Wales Department of Agriculture, which has the responsibility for State fisheries in New South Wales. The reference in this debate to the intention to assist in the financing of a new research vessel for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) is an important consideration but again there is the vital question of co-ordination with the respective States. New South Wales already has a research vessel. One would imagine that the vessel now proposed for the CSIRO will have much greater capacity to do surveys and will be equipped with the kind of sophisticated equipment that these days is essential for research of the sort that must be carried out in very deep water in the various fishing grounds to ascertain fish stocks, the reasons for the advent of fish in certain zones and why we have lost the fish resource in so many parts of Australia.

It is very easy for those who criticise the fishermen or those who have engaged in the commercial activities in the past, whether it be in whaling or the taking of catches of larger fish such as tuna where it is known that there is not an unlimited resource. But co-ordination between the Federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the fishing industry organisations at national level, this new research committee and the State authorities can do a great deal to encourage and to protect the Australian fishing industry. That surely is the objective of the legislation before the House this afternoon. The problems that I mentioned that face the individual fishermen are great-finance, the success of their individual ventures and the co-ordination through co-operatives or fish marketing authorities for effective marketing. So there is always some apprehension about the raising of additional funds, the introduction of increased levies and licensing requirements.

In the matters before us there is a reference to licensing being for periods other than 12 months. I do not know what the import of that is but I hope that it is not intended as some draconian process to reduce further the viability of the existing fishermen. In New South Wales in the last few months there was a move afoot which spelt out an intention of a new policy that the licence of a fishing boat would not automatically be renewed if the holder of the licence was no longer able to operate the boat. That would mean that if there were a death in a fishing family-very often they are family businesses-the licence could not be passed on to the successor or could not be sold, if there was a need for a father to sell to a son or some other move of that kind. I think good sense has prevailed to some extent and that this proposition is now being reviewed.

All of us understand that there must be limits-limits on catches, on the scope of fishing-but the limits must also be administered in a manner which recognises individual rights and the need for reward for enterprise. There is no industry in which one more often finds small business, the enterprise of the kind that comes from family ventures, from individual effort, than in this industry. Certainly, there are some big companies but usually they have a role in co-ordinating, in taking the catches from the individual fishermen and arranging for processing and then marketing. So they do have an important role, but our concern primarily must be for the individual fishermen because without them we would not have an industry of the sort we have today.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been the backbone so far.

—And we would not, as the honourable member for Lyne says, be able to sustain the backbone of the industry that has been built up over the years. Unless we do that we will lose our export markets. We would than have to import more fish, which of course would be a disadvantage for the overall economy, and we would not make progress for Australia of the sort that is so necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention one aspect that relates to all of this potential. What do we find? The freight cost for the export of much of our take today has sky-rocketed. For example, those who have undertaken the development of boats capable of catching tuna off the east coast, of handling the tuna, of getting it on to a cargo flight out of this country, which means it reaches its market in a matter of hours, were doing the job precisely and efficiently and getting a very good result on the Tokyo fish market with catches from the waters off the east coast of Australia. From places in my electorate such as Evans Head, Ballina and Coffs Harbour the catch is on the Japanese market in a matter of only hours, less than 24 hours, with a level of efficiency and a quality result that a few years ago were thought to have been quite impossible for Australian fishermen. What has happened to them in the last few weeks? There has been a 25 per cent increase in the freight rate from our own airline, Qantas. That is a very severe blow for fishermen who have built up efficiency of the sort that I have just described and who then have had the great disappointment to find the imposition of a freight hike of that sort on top of enormous increases over the last 18 months. So I hope that some of our research effort will go into some of these commercial considerations because they are inseparable from the success of the industry. In that respect, research ought to be on issues such as the weight factors, the packing factors, what can be done to ensure that the best possible facilities are there to enable an export industry of that kind to be sustained, to be efficient and to be contained within the cost structure that enables the individual fisherman to do his job, to do it well and to do it not only in his own interests but also in the interests of a very important industry and in the interests of Australia.

In the main, I commend the Government on the proposals. I have raised a number of matters that I hope will be given consideration. I hope that the Minister for Resources will, as he has done in so many other spheres over a period, ensure that the welfare of this industry is paramount in the administration of the funds that are raised through the research levies proposed in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was pleased to hear the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) raise some fundamental issues concerning the fishing industry. I wish to speak on a few of those issues. I am sure the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) does not mind, because he knows that I have some knowledge of the fishing industry, having chaired a parliamentary select committee on the industry in the New South Wales Parliament in 1974-75. Naturally, the matters dealt with by that committee were more or less confined to State affairs of the industry, but what constitutes State affairs is basically also the Commonwealth's responsibility, because the situations are similar.

SPEECH.PARA: It is exciting to see the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill, the Fishing Industry Research Amendment Bill and the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill before the Parliament because they deal with an industry that holds a wonderful future for our fishermen, for all Australians and for our economy and the balance of trade. I often think of the industry's wonderful potential for development. The honourable member for Page spoke about the manner in which the environmentalists are using pressure to close the estuaries to fishing and basically to leave them to the amateurs. I am sure that this will continue as time goes on. However, the broad area of sea around Australia provides a tremendous challenge for us to locate, research, catch and deal with the very great fish resource that exists around the continent. I am pleased to see that greater research is embodied and foreseen in the legislation before the House. I am pleased that a Commonwealth vessel-I will not query its operations because I can recall the Kapala in New South Wales which carried out much valuable research-is to be provided to go further afield around the shores of Australia to locate fish and prawns and the other resources that we know are there.

There has always been a query as to whether we can fish out a resource. I have heard the fish biologists discuss on a number of occasions whether the States should have closed fisheries. I do not know. I will not enter that debate, but I believe that, with careful management, we can sustain the fish resource that we have around Australia. We must always keep in mind that a lot of that resource comprises the migratory fish from areas that have been fished out by other countries. We know that up to 400 overseas fishing boats have been fishing around the Australian shores for years. They are certainly affecting the resource that we are debating today. I am sure that there is a greater understanding of this, with the International Convention on the Law of the Sea and other negotiations between the continents concerned, and that we will be able to have a greater share of the existing resource.

The Japanese, the Poles, the South Africans or the Taiwanese may have a greater knowledge of the fishing grounds around the Australian continent than we do. This is an important aspect. It is possible that this is the case because they study the currents and know the migratory trend of the fish and are therefore able to assess, as a miner is able to locate the ore, where the fish will be-and they go after the fish. This is a logical thing to occur.

I come back to what the honourable member for Page has said. His electorate, like mine, is on the eastern coast of Australia, and we have a fair bit to do with fishermen. We should never forget that the fisherman is an individualist. He is like the farmer. It is hard to organise him, but fishermen have come together over the years through sheer necessity. From my knowledge of them, and I am sure the Minister will agree with me, there are today fishermen within the industry who are competent and capable of managing their own affairs. This is an important factor. They are men who know about the operation of the catch and the processing and packaging of the fish and what the consumer wants. This is important for our catch and its distribution. I am sure that those people, who are managing the co-operatives and serving upon the various State and Commonwealth fishing committees, are quite capable of serving on the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council. They are capable of conducting and administering the industry in the way we would like to see.

I am sometimes concerned about the smaller operator within the industry, who has been spoken about in this debate. The smaller operator, as the honourable member for Page said, is the backbone of the industry. We used to see him in the estuaries pulling or pushing his boat around, catching the mullet. He had a roller on the back of his pulling boat with which he ran out the net and hauled it in on the shores of the rivers. This happens also in our seas. Many people object to mullet being caught at spawning times. I suppose there is a logical reason for objecting to that. But these small fishermen are the people who founded the industry. Their problems today, as the honourable member for Page said, lie in the costs of acquiring the vessels and the plant to enable them to operate efficiently either within the estuaries or right out to sea.

If I were to enter the fishing industry today as a small man with one or two deckhands, I estimate that to go outside a 15- or 20-mile area would cost a quarter of a million dollars. There would be the cost of purchasing a boat, of equipping it with plant and equipping the operators to take the catch. It costs at least $100 a night, if a fisherman is to do his job, to take a diesel boat out at night to fish and come back in the morning. The cost of refrigeration is high. This is high cost industry generally for the operator.

I am concerned in particular with the $295 charge introduced in the Budget. I ask the Minister to explain the reason for that. I have had many objections within the electorate of Lyne from people who feel that that extra cost is a burden that they should not bear. There are freight costs and the costs of processing, which are well beyond the registration costs of the boats, et cetera. I understand that approximately 6,000 fishermen are registered with the Commonwealth or the States to operate vessels in Commonwealth waters.

I know that time is short. I have listed a few of the issues that concern me. I hope that we can continue research and that we can build research up. I hope that the Government will confer more and more with members of the industry, because they have the ability to assist and should have some say in the direction that research is to take. Undoubtedly, the industry will go ahead if this is the case. We must always keep in mind that our best market for fish is in Australia, on our own doorstep. It is lovely to see the little co-operatives that are scattered up and down the coast supplying their fresh fish on the floor of the market in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth or Brisbane and to know that there is room either within the fishing co-operative concerned or on the marketing floor to process the extra catch. The industry produces a glut of fish at certain times of the year-for instance, flathead and mullet from the coastal areas, for which fishermen almost receive an account and not a cheque, because of oversupply. A lot of the problems in the industry have been overcome. The industry in Australia faces a new front and, as I said earlier, a very exciting future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members who have participated in this afternoon's debate-the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd); the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker); the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow); the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell); the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright); the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey); the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite); the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson); and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan). I am pleased that the Opposition supports the package of fishing industry Bills before the House. Some minor differences have been raised, and a number of issues. I will do my best, within the available time, to deal with those that have been brought to my attention by honourable members. I was unable to be in the chamber during the contributions of the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Wannon and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in my second reading speech, the fisheries industry is undergoing a profound change. As honourable members have reiterated during the debate, it is an industry with a growing future. There is a finite limit on the resources that are available within the industry. There is a responsibility upon those at a State and Federal government level, members of this chamber and those within the industry itself to manage those resources wisely. That matter was mentioned by the honourable member for Page. A number of decisions made by government over recent weeks bear upon this. The Australian Fisheries Council-that is, the State and Federal Ministers responsible for fisheries-met last Friday in Melbourne. At that meeting the Council resolved, in respect of the southern shark fishery, that there be a reduction in the effort being applied. Details of that are contained in a statement which we released on Friday, 23 October. Similarly, on the same day I announced, with the responsible Minister in Queensland, Minister Harper, new entry criteria for the Torres Strait prawn fishery. We stated that, under the new arrangement, vessel licences for the prawn fishery and the Australian component of the Torres Strait protected zone would be renewed after 1 January 1988 only if the vessels had operated in the fishery in any two years during the period 1 January 1984 to 31 December 1986. The problem there is that of the 500 vessels that are licensed to operate only about 130 actually trawled in that period. We want to get the fishery back to a level of effort that is commensurate with the resources that are there. It is part of this overall approach of carefully, wisely and responsibly utilising the finite resource that is there.

On 28 September I announced-this was referred to by one of the speakers in the debate-the Government's decision to invite interested parties to express their interest in a new development plan for the section of coast out to some 200 nautical miles between Barranjoey Point, which is effectively the Hawkesbury River, and Cape York. We are looking there at deep water fishing and at vessels with a recent history of successful trawling at depths greater than 900 metres, with priority being given to suitable Australian fishing boat operators. Again, during the debate a number of speakers referred to resources. There are resources there. We are sure of that. We do not know how much. Even the honourable member for Lyne, in his concluding remarks, referred to other countries which, in his opinion, know more about our resources, their extent, their variety and their nature, than we do.

The point that he made and which I make is that we need to explore. We need to carry out greater research to note carefully what resources, to the best of our knowledge, are there. Having determined that, we need to manage them in as efficient a manner as possible. The honourable member referred also to the migratory species that move around in the various waters. Again, that comes back to the question of knowledge and the need for research. The honourable member referred to the fee of $295 that has been levied. It is part of the approach that those who utilise the services provided to the industry should meet the costs of the services provided to the industry. I will give the honourable member a note later explaining how the figure was arrived at.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it was stated in the Budget announcement of new initiatives. That doesn't sound like a new initiative.

—I will also make that available to the Deputy Leader of the National Party. The honourable member for Page also raised the issue of air freight rates. Given that the approach for sectors of the industry is to target certain species and market niches, if we are to use an expensive form of freight such as air freight, the provision of that service must be on a commercial basis. There is no future in trying to build a business, industry or market based upon a service that is provided on an as-available kind of basis. The people who fly aeroplanes also want to earn a return. They also want a reward for the provision of their service. That market is very much an open market. The opportunity is there to provide an air freight service if there are customers who are able to use it at the rates that need to be charged to ensure that there is a return for both parties involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the National Party referred to accountability for levies that are raised. All levies are raised to offset government expenditure on managed fisheries, in accordance with detailed fishery management budgets that have been discussed fully with the industry and the fishery concerned. The increased percentage recovery is based on the application of the Government's user pay principle and the intention of increasing the rate of recovery over the next three years. I understand that the honourable member referred to an 84 per cent on-cost. I can advise him that this is the standard on-cost percentage that is used for this purpose. In respect of the size of the Australian Fisheries Service, the additional positions are being used to implement the Government's new policy proposals that were announced in the Budget. In respect of the review of fishery management institutional arrangements, I will be announcing details of the scope and structure of the inquiry into the administration of Commonwealth fisheries in the next few weeks. There are a few details yet to be put into place.

The one point to make out of all this is that we must move to a situation whereby those who use the services contribute to the cost of providing them. That is the revenue side of the equation. On the other side of the equation is expenditure. With expenditure goes efficiency. Not only is there an obligation upon the users of the services to contribute to the costs of providing them but also there is an obligation upon government and the service itself to ensure that we carry out our task in an efficient manner. We will certainly be looking at that. It is not just a matter of revenue covering costs; it is a matter of ensuring that the tasks are carried out in an efficient and reliable manner. That is given as far as I am concerned.

The issue of industry participating more fully in the management of fisheries will be taken up in the inquiry. That has been brought to my attention and I understand it. The proper way to deal with it is not by an ad hoc decision by government or me, but rather in the overall approach to the review of institutional arrangements that I mentioned earlier. The honourable member for Wannon referred to value added products. The Government is looking at the value added aspects of fishery products. We agree that there is scope to extend the range of seafoods produced in Australia.

I make the point that, coming from a region such as that of the honourable member for Lyne and the honourable member for Page, I have had some little knowledge over the years of the fisheries industry, not in the detail required by the legislation before the House but in earlier years. There has to be an absolute reliability on quality standards. That is one area in which we have room for improvement. If we are to expand our market I believe that there is significant potential for product innovation. There are many fish products at the moment for which greater markets could be developed if there was a bit more innovation in the processing of those products and those fisheries. There needs to be a greater targeting of markets. All of those things are happening. As I mentioned previously, we are going through a period of profound change for the industry. I have every confidence that the industry will rise to the challenges that are before it and to the opportunities that exist for it.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie referred to the issue of sport fishermen versus professional fishermen. Under the off-shore constitutional settlement, this is a matter for the State governments. Different States have different views. I am sure that that is a matter that will resolve itself as time progresses. The views he expressed have been expressed by a number of other members.

In regard to the comments by the honourable member for O'Connor about the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council, and research generally, the Fishing Industry Research and Development Council will be able to direct research and development resources to the development of the resource, including problems such as the crown-of-thorn starfish, the operation of fishing businesses and their problems, such as the means of cost containment. Again, that is a matter of business and enterprise efficiency. The industry, in the process of becoming more professional, will have to look at this matter.

I referred in my second reading speech to the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account and the fact that it has supported scientific and biological research in many Australian fisheries.
