I repeat that it has provided funds for exploratory fishing projects, fishing gear technology studies, education for fishermen and research into the handling and marketing of fish and fish products. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), universities, government agencies, fishing companies and individual fishermen have received funding from the account to undertake research. The existing rural industries research council findings has proved to be heavily implemented. If one refers to that as an example, one can expect that, in respect of the fishing industry, there will also be a high uptake of the Research and Development Council's research results. Overall, that has provided a good return to industry and to government. The annual reports to be submitted by the Council will be a means of accounting for research results.

The honourable member for O'Connor also mentioned the research vessel for the CSIRO. The Cabinet decision has been that, if the CSIRO gets a new vessel, the money in the old fund will be available to help pay for it. But the report of the consultant engaged to advise the CSIRO has yet to be delivered. Since the report has not been received, no decision has been taken. The receipt of the report, and the consideration of recommendations in that report, are matters for future consideration when they come to hand.

The honourable member for Capricornia referred to a number of matters, such as assistance to fishermen, access to low cost loans and insurance problems. They are all problems that can be dealt with by the Research and Development Council as it develops in the industry, as it develops its expertise and as the level of participation increases.

I conclude by thanking those honourable members who participated in the debate. It has been a constructive and, in the main, positive debate that has been supported by the Opposition. The industry does have a great opportunity before it, but it must pick up that opportunity. There must be an increasing level of initiative and an increasing level of professionalism. As we move towards improving arrangements with the States under the off-shore constitutional settlement, the development of the Research Council-the things I have already mentioned-and the review of the existing Commonwealth institutional arrangements, I have every confidence that we are looking at an industry that can make a greater contribution to export income. I commend the package of Bills to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the replacement explanatory memorandum to the Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill 1987. This replacement is necessary because the original contained a citation error. The amendment does not affect the substance of the memorandum. I note that copies of the replacement memorandum have been distributed to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill is to seek the repeal of the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977 and to make certain consequential amendments to the Banking Act 1959. The former Act is now redundant, following the sale of the Government's interest in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA) to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia, and the granting of a banking authority to the Primary Industry Bank under section 9 of the Banking Act. The Primary Industry Bank, of course, was established in 1978 under the provision of an Act of this Parliament. Its role was specifically to provide long term funding to the rural sector through a refinance facility. Prior to its acquisition by the Rural and Industries Bank, the Commonwealth had a 12.5 per cent shareholding and the four major trading banks, and a consortium of four State banks, each had 17.5 per cent of the shares.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government argues that the deregulation of the financial system resulted in there being no further need for direct Commonwealth involvement in the bank. Also, the bank's multiple ownership by a consortium of other financial institutions, and the Commonwealth, was proving unwieldy. These are, in our view, reasonable arguments. Indeed, I am aware that in some aspects of its operations the unusual ownership by so many other competing banks hampered the ability of PIBA satisfactorily to provide its flexible loan facilities. However, the real reason behind the Government's motives for selling its interest in PIBA is centred on the $2.5m it received. Those receipts have been counted against the Government's major asset sales for the 1987-88 Budget. What that represents is not really a commitment to efficiency, but a commitment by this Government to fund unjustifiably high levels of public expenditure by an ever-increasing rise in revenue collection.

This exercise is simply another effort by the Government to rake in the cash, and it is developing into a habit. Like a junkie it needs to get larger and larger fixes to satisfy its unseemly habit. And, like a junkie, that habit, unless stopped in its tracks, will lead to the inevitable decay of the body economic. In one area, the evidence of the decay, caused by this Government's inadequate policies, is obvious, that is, the Australian Labor Party's debt-the quadrupling of our foreign debt under the Hawke Labor Government-the $83 million foreign debt that has been allowed to accumulate.

Honourable members will be aware that the Budget Papers record that total revenue collections have increased by around 75 per cent over the course of this Government's term in office. In 1987-88 alone revenue is to increase by $5.5 billion over the previous year-$5.5 billion in additional revenue. And the sale of assets, like the one being provided for in this Bill, is simply a belated means that this Government has found as its scratches around to finance its next hit of increased expenditures. I realise that $2.5m, on a national scale in the Budget, is not much; but when you are desperate, every little bit helps. But it does not really help, not in reality. It simply postpones the day when the needed quality expenditure cuts will be made. No wonder Senator Peter Walsh, the Government's own Minister for Finance, is frightened by the prospect of going further down the Argentinean road.

Honourable members will already be aware of our arguments that asset sales should not be counted as reducing the Budget deficit. The proceeds from assets sales should go to retire debt, not to assist in funding the deficit. When there is $1 billion of asset sales, there is $1 billion of underlying deficit. Of course, in addition it is legitimate to add to that the one-off nature of the Reserve Bank and Mint profits, on which the Government is relying for financing its 1987-88 Budget on top of the proceeds of asset sales.

That has led us to say time and again that the process of adjustment of domestic policies in the face of the blowout in our external difficulties is just too slow. The Government is not moving fast enough to address our problems-to allow us adequately to cope with precipitous external shocks such as the current great share market tumble. But in addition, the sale of PIBA raises again the important public debate of privatisation. The Labor Party is at sixes and sevens over this debate. There is this ideology soul-searching by the socialists across the floor. The arguments of Ben Chifley for nationalisation are being brought into question. Ben Chifley's philosophies, the hardened, seemingly deep-rooted philophies of Labor, are allegedly being turned on their head. But are they seeing the real light, the light of rational economic discussion that we in the Opposition support, as against their dear, fast and seemingly fastened, mystic but moribund socialist `light on the hill'. It is extremely hard to tell.

We all recall the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sermonising that only the devil incarnate would venture to support privatisation-that crude 13-letter word, according to Labor. Let me quote the man. On 21 November 1985, in this House, the current Prime Minister stated:
They know, as anyone who thinks about the issue of privatisation knows, that it would mean higher prices, higher costs, higher taxes and higher fares.

What a monstrous prospect he sought to paint. Yet after the recent election, the very same Prime Minister began to talk of the necessity of reviewing the Government's privatisation policy. We will not worry here about the fact that his senior Ministers seemed a little confused about the manner in which the Prime Minister initiated the debate. We can remember Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Button, those Ministers carrying the major responsibilities for bodies ripe for sale, criticising the Prime Minister for his lack of finesse and blundering style. That is their criticism, not just ours.

Instead, we must ask why the Prime Minister has done a back flip. Why has he changed his story? I doubt that the real reasons have much to do with the allocative efficiency of resources. The reasons lie more at the heart of the Government's inability appropriately to address the need for outlay reductions. This Labor Government now realises that many of those authorities it owns will soon need large injections of capital, especially the airlines, Qantas and Australian Airlines. In addition, those authorities involved in communications-Telecom, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and Aussat-also have huge capital requirements so as to maintain their grasp on new technologies. Capital requirements involve funding straight from the Budget, or borrowing under the Loan Council arrangements. The Government is scared of the prospect of payments from the Budget because it knows that it has not made, nor is it prepared to make, enough quality cuts to provide room for more legitimate types of capital expenditure such as these. That means either higher tax receipts or allowing the authorities to borrow themselves. Not even a destructive government such as this one, which has been neglectful of the effect of the taxation burdens on the ordinary Australian, could seriously contemplate further heavy imposts. Nor do I think the Government wants to resort to any further increase in the Budget deficit.

Another alternative is for the authorities to borrow directly to meet their needs. Nonetheless, that also will affect the public sector borrowing requirement (PSBR) directly and, more importantly, make it difficult for the Commonwealth to convince the State governments to rein in the borrowing programs of their authorities under the Loan Council arrangements.

So it is obvious that a main reason for contemplating privatisation is that the Government has forced itself into a corner. Reducing the PSBR is a commendable policy. The best way to do that is to cut recurrent expenditures. Therefore, I am concerned that the Government may be forced into unnecessarily quick sales, to the detriment of taxpayers, because of its inability to make the necessary outlay cuts elsewhere. Nonetheless, while given these concerns, and the fact that the Government's reasons are basically confused, the results it achieves by selling many of these authorities hold the prospect of being very beneficial. We in the Opposition have always supported free enterprise over government ownership, and the associated incentives that involves will, in the main, deliver the society to its greatest potential.

Of course, there are situations in the markets which can legitimately involve a government. Some type of intervention will sometimes be warranted. However, that will not necessarily justify the need for public ownership. In many cases, resort to subsidies, taxation concessions or trade practices legislation will be preferable. Such issues can be very involved. They require calm and rational debate within the community. In the process, the return of many publicly owned assets to private hands will not be detrimental but, rather, advantageous to the consumer. It will remove future burdens on the taxpayer.

It is interesting to note that PIBA was bought by the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia, which is itself owned by the Western Australian Government. We in the Opposition would have been happier if it had been sold to the private sector. Indeed, we propose further asset sales along the guidelines which we hope the Government will adopt. They are: First, there must be demonstrable benefits to consumers and/or taxpayers; secondly, the position and job security of existing employees will be given special consideration and sale of shares to employees will be encouraged whenever possible; thirdly, the quality and availability of services to remote areas will not be allowed to deteriorate; fourthly, any large scale sales will be timed so as to avoid disruption of capital markets; and fifthly, sale proceeds will not be used to finance new government expenditure but will be directed towards reducing the accumulated public debt.

I wish to conclude by saying that we commend the sale of PIBA by the Commonwealth Government, and accordingly do not oppose the Bill. Nonetheless, we doubt the Government's questionable motives in doing so and again urge it to focus greater attention on expenditure cutting, rather than asset sales, to reduce the public sector's call on financial markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-(Quorum formed) The Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill repeals the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977. Government interest in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA) has been sold to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia. The sale resulted in revenue to the Commonwealth of $2.5m for its 12 1/2 per cent shareholding. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), used the debate to launch into a diatribe about privatisation. Typically, he had two bob each way and, while he pointed out that the Government should be cautious about selling its own properties, he also applauded the practice.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an enormous difference between the manner in which the Opposition deals with government ownership and the way the Government deals with it. Where the Opposition is religious about privatisation, for instance of Telecom Australia, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and Australia Post-in fact they would all go if the Liberals had their way-the Government looks at each industry separately. The Government has not been forced into a corner on the future of PIBA and it does not make unnecessary quick sales. It looked at Australian Airlines, for instance, and appreciated the fact that that airline had been hampered by a number of requirements of government. I believe that through the deregulation policy and subsequent policies the Government will assist Australian Airlines to compete more fairly in the commercial sector.

PIBA no longer requires Federal Government involvement. The relationship, within the ownership, between the consortium of banks and the Commonwealth has been described by the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), as having become unwieldy. Fortunately, the Government sought to ensure that the rural sector would not be disadvantaged in its access to PIBA banking services and would be represented on the PIBA Board.

The recently released annual report of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia issued on 22 October 1987 makes a number of important points about the record of PIBA. It shows clearly that PIBA is certainly not in a decline, that it is an ongoing, useful organisation assisting primary industry in particular. For instance, the report states:

In order to maintain a competitive position in world markets, Australian primary producers have a need to be constantly improving their properties. The funding of capital improvements is often built into a PIBA financing package.
The purchase of land is the purpose for which PIBA's funds are most often used. Successful farmers are matching improved technology and management skills with increased farming areas.
In the initial years of a land purchase, it is important to have a flexible loan facility that does not demand principal reductions and thus allows a breathing space for progressive growth.
The report also mentions the participation of PIBA in pasture improvement. The report states:
Australian farmers are encouraged to ensure that this country's national land assets are preserved in a condition that is conducive to ongoing productivity.

Agriculture is one sector of the Australian economy that can be truly described as being based on a `renewable resource'. It is important that the quality of this resource be maintained for the present and future generations.
PIBA's interest-only facility fits in well with this type of programme as it does not require repayment of principal before the benefits can come to fruition.
In referring to livestock the report states:
An essential element of the management of Australia's livestock industries is a regular upgrading and culling programme. This aspect can be accommodated within the PIBA loan package.

Stocking programmes can be adjusted to take advantage of the extra feed available during good seasons or when opportunistic market conditions appear. The timing of consignment of stock to the saleyard must have some degree of flexibility if maximum prices are to be obtained. PIBA recognises this aspect and is able to provide the required degree of flexibility in its loan packages.
Similarly it is recognised that a period of herd or flock build-up can be a time when loan flexibility is important to the borrower.
The Primary Industry Bank of Australia is able to come in where often the client's own bank is unable to come in. In regard to working capital the report states:

Much of Australia's agricultural areas are subject to drought, fire, flood or plagues at some time. It is important to have a bank that understands these potential difficulties and can help when the time comes.

Against a background of seasonal uncertainty and price variations, it is often difficult for a farmer to plan principal repayments without jeopardising future working capital. To this end PIBA can restructure existing borrowings to increase the funds available for working capital.
Similarly, dissolution of farm partnerships or untimely death can often require flexibility in loan arrangements. It is important to have a bank that can be helpful at these times.

PIBA has very often come to the party. In conclusion, I mention that PIBA is a growing bank. Offices have been opened in the previous financial year in Brisbane and in Perth. The after tax profit increase of 22.5 per cent over the previous year's profit was an excellent record. A full and unrestricted national banking authority was granted to the bank in June 1987. In the 1986-87 financial year, the bank achieved total self-sufficiency in its operations with the repayment of the balance of loan moneys advanced to it by the Commonwealth of Australia. I join other members in congratulating the Primary Industry Bank of Australia on its record and wishing it well under the new arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to endorse the remarks of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) congratulating the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA) on its performance. It certainly has proved to be a very sound bank, unlike some others. I might come back to that in a minute. I have to take exception to what he said about the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), when he talked about his having two bob each way on privatisation. He obviously completely misheard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition because he was talking very clearly about the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) having two bob each way. For the benefit of honourable members present, I will repeat some of the words of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition earlier in this debate. He was quoting none other than the Prime Minister himself. I think it is worth reminding all honourable members that it was only in 1985, in fact on 21 November 1985, in this chamber, that the Prime Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: They know, as anyone who thinks about the issue of privatisation knows, that it would mean higher prices, higher costs, higher taxes and higher fares.

Yet it is remarkable, talking about two bob each way, to see the complete back flip of the present Government on the issue of privatisation as soon as the election is over. Whilst no-one is arguing about the sale of the Government's minority shareholding in the Primary Industry Bank to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia, the point is that this is a form of privatisation-nothing more and nothing less. I think the member for Eden-Monaro ought to check his facts on that matter because the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was quite clear on it when he was talking about the Government's two-faced approach to privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! Well said.

—I thank the honourable member. The Primary Industry Bank does have a very good record. I was very heartened to read in the latest annual report, the 1987 annual report, that the Chairman, when speaking of the transfer of the Commonwealth's share ownership to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia, said that the bank's head office is to remain in Sydney and special emphasis will continue to be given to its business operations in the rural sector. That is very heartening to hear because it has certainly played a very important role in the rural industries ever since it was begun by the previous Government in 1978. I notice also in the Chairman's address that, with its growth and profit, it is now the seventh largest banking organisation in Australia, which is quite an achievement in just on 10 years. I think all honourable members would be quite happy to congratulate the bank on that effort.

SPEECH.PARA: My comments tonight will be confined mostly to the role of the old income equalisation deposit scheme, as it was under the previous Government, and its connection with the Primary Industry Bank. As some honourable members will remember, the income equalisation deposit scheme was begun by the previous Government as a means of trying to help primary producers not only to iron out some of the fluctuations in their incomes which, unfortunately, with the best will in the world is unavoidable, but also as a self-help measure to try to get primary producers to put money aside in the good years and to be able to draw on it in the bad years so that they could remain quite self-sufficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —And prudent.

—And prudent. I thank the honourable member. There is also another point about the income equalisation deposit scheme which should not be forgotten. It was a means of trying to bring fairness and equity into the tax system as it affects primary producers. As honourable members will know, if they do their homework and their sums, someone on a fluctuating income will pay more tax on the total amount of income over a number of years than someone who is on a constant income. This is a point that seems to have been forgotten by the Government when it was so quick to kill the scheme in 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: We listened to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in his diatribe today about fairness and equity. He seems to have blinkered vision when it comes to thinking about what fairness and equity is in the tax system as it affects people on fluctuating incomes-not just primary producers, but also some of our professional sportsmen who find themselves in a similar situation. It was rather unfortunate that the Government chose to knock off the income equalisation deposit scheme in 1984. It did have the scope to assist the Primary Industry Bank and in 1978 the opportunity was made available to the Primary Industry Bank, although the bank did not actually take it up, for income equalisation deposit scheme deposits that were held by the Commonwealth to be advanced to the Primary Industry Bank as a means of giving it low interest finance.

As honourable members will remember, the income equalisation deposit scheme had a fairly low return of interest, partly because it was a means of smoothing out income. Farmers could defer income in a year of high returns and withdraw their deposits in a year of low returns, thereby deferring a tax payment until the year that they withdrew those deposits. Accordingly, there was only a relatively low rate of interest. Those funds were offered to the Primary Industry Bank in 1978 as a means of reducing marginally, not dramatically, the interest rates that the Primary Industry Bank could then charge on the money it was lending out to the primary industry. It was a very good opportunity for the Primary Industry Bank and while it did not actually avail itself of those funds it did allow it to borrow at a slightly more favourable rate because the people who were lending the money to it knew that PIBA had this opportunity, and therefore additional security, when they made loans to the bank.

In passing, it should also be mentioned that the income equalisation deposit scheme should be reintroduced. I hope that the Government will have another look at it because there is no doubt that such a scheme provides one of the best avenues for farmers to smooth out their fluctuating incomes, to be able to look after themselves when the bad times come, as invariably they do-as all wheat farmers will tell us, they are right on their doorsteps now-and it also gives them the opportunity not to have to pay more tax than someone who is on a reasonably constant income. Because there is a sliding scale of income tax rates, someone who has no income one year and a relatively larger income the following year will pay more tax than the person who earns the mean of that income over the same two years.

I would also like to remind honourable members that the income equalisation deposit scheme did not interfere with market forces, which was very important when it came to giving market signals back to the rural producer. It had significant advantages over any market stabilisation scheme that tended to blur the income that a commodity was earning from one year to the next. It was also a voluntary scheme, so there was no obligation in it and farmers could go into it or leave the scheme according to their circumstances.

When talking about the Primary Industry Bank, I think it is probably worth drawing some comparisons with what is happening in the agricultural banks in the United States of America (USA). I think we are very fortunate that we have not seen this happen in Australia. We are unlikely to see it happen in Australia because our banking system, particularly amongst the one or two agricultural banks, has been far more responsible in its approach to lending. I will quote from a very interesting article in May this year from the Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis. The article is entitled `Agricultural Banks: Causes of Failures and the Conditions of Survivors'. It is something a bit foreign to us in more ways than one because we have not seen an agricultural bank do something like this. The article states:
The number of bank failures-
this is in the United States-
has risen sharply in recent years. From 1943 to 1981, no more than 17 commercial banks ever failed in a single year. Since 1982, when 34 banks failed-
that is double the number-
the number of failures has risen each year, reaching 144 in 1986.
In the years 1984 through 1986, about half of the 340 failed banks were agricultural banks.
Agricultural banks make up about one-third of all banks.

I have no doubt that it is important to note these statistics. They give a very ominous warning about the state of agriculture in the United States. While we are quick to condemn the United States for its support for farmers, I think we have to ameliorate some of our comments a little bit with the realisation that farmers in the United States have been going through fairly tough times as well. I guess the message from all that is that government support in the long run will not put farmers in a stronger position than less government support.

In talking about the Primary Industry Bank, it is worth looking at the economic climate we are facing today. I do not think in an opportunity like this I should miss pointing out some of the real concerns of people in the farming industry, the people who have been forced to avail themselves of the banks such as the Primary Industry Bank when, in many cases, they probably wished they had not. I am just talking about the general state of the Australian economy today, particularly its state in the last week or so. It was pointed out in the debate earlier today by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that Australia has some serious economic problems, whichever way one looks at it. We had a so-called favourable response to the Budget which was finally punctured when the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) gave a slightly more frank account of the situation than the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was prepared to give.

When we look beneath the surface of the Australian economy, we see cause for concern. Again and again, we have spoken about Australia's rising overseas debt. In gross terms it has trebled under this Government. The Treasurer keeps talking about the fundamentals, and this is a fundamental which, by any measure, is bad. As the Leader of the Opposition pointed out today, our overseas debt is 40 per cent of our gross domestic product (GDP) while the overseas debt of the US is only 13 per cent. While we may be concerned for other reasons about the US economy, on the question of overseas debt, there is no doubt that we are in a much more parlous situation than it is.

Allowing for inflation, again taking the Leader of the Opposition's figures, as he pointed out so clearly, our overseas debt, expressed as a percentage of GDP, has doubled in the last four years. Again, this is great cause for concern, and it is an even greater cause for concern when we look at the balance of trade figures. Last month there was another dramatic adverse trade figure. Whichever way you look at it, this is cause for concern. We are still going further into debt. When we talk about the warnings and the fundamentals, by any measure the 1985 drop in the value of the Australian dollar was as clear a warning as anyone would have needed to tell us that there was something fundamentally wrong with the Australian economy. Yet, the Treasurer chose to ignore this warning and to continue to talk up the state of our economy. Later on, we found that our AAA credit rating was wiped out. However, he still chose to ignore it until last year when he made some reference, almost in an aside, to a banana republic, and almost as soon as he made that reference, he seemed to forget it.

In this light, we must look at what happened on the stock markets in the last week. The dramatic downturn in share market prices, even though it has come from a very high level, is a cause for some concern. I do not want to play it up to anything more than that at this stage. There is a risk of two things. First of all, there is the effect it could have on the Budget revenue, which could be quite significant. The other even more serious concern is that, should it not be handled very carefully and skilfully, there is a real risk in a loss of confidence not just in the share market but in wider aspects of the Australian economy. I suggest this is something that the Australian Government ought to be addressing and taking far more seriously than the Treasurer would have us believe. The situation with the Rothwells bank is a stark reminder of how seriously the business community takes some of the things that have happened in the last week. If the Government ignores that, it does so at its own peril.

One of the clearest warnings, which the Treasurer ought to have taken, was from the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, his colleague in the Senate, who was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 21 September, a month ago, as saying, when talking about Australia:

A country which has a high level of foreign debt and a continuing large current account deficit is a country which has few options. We've been a lucky country for a long time, not so lucky any more, and if we don't challenge--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not so lucky any more, not since the government changed.
—Yes, since the government changed. Senator Walsh continued:

SPEECH.PARA: We've been a lucky country for a long time, not so lucky any more, and if we don't challenge most of the absurd notions that the majority of Australians have about what they are entitled to and what's essential to them and what isn't, then we are going down the Argentinean road.
That is a stark warning, if ever there was one, about the fundamentals-something at which the Treasurer ought to be looking far more seriously.
Even today, in the Age, there is another clear warning. In its editorial, it made this stark warning to the Government about the fundamentals:
The crash demands fundamental change.
Nothing could be clearer. The Age editorial continues:
How sound the ``economic fundamentals'' are is a matter of debate.
The Treasurer wants to use the word `fundamental' and here it is in one of our leading newspapers in Australia, which is drawing his attention to it. It continues:

The recent market collapse has deepened that concern, although not to the point where comparisons with the 1929 crash . . . are compelling. But no one should allow the necessary expressions of hope and caution to mask the facts. The ``fundamentals'' are not so sound that a severe recession can be ruled out.
That is a very clear warning.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do about it?

—One has only to listen--

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I would like to endorse the words of those who have congratulated the Primary Industry Bank on what it has achieved so far and to wish it every success in what is going on. The Government has recognised that, and the major instrument for achieving change in this area is through the rural adjustment scheme. Under a new rural adjustment scheme, assistance is available through a 50 per cent interest subsidy for debt reconstruction, farm build-up and farm improvement by primary producers in need who are viable in the long term but unable to obtain commercial finance. Household support and rehabilitation assistance are also available for non-viable producers in need who are considering leaving the industry.

The rural adjustment scheme is expected to cost $42m this financial year compared with $34m last financial year. Of this amount, $6.7m is for new loans under the interest subsidy component of the scheme. While this represents a reduction on the level of new lending from last year, reflecting budgetary circumstances and the improved rural outlook, I point out that I hope that members opposite understand that there is in fact an improved rural outlook. In fact, I was chatting to the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) just before I started speaking and I pointed out that the farmers in my electorate are primarily fine wool producers who are receiving top prices for their wool at the moment. I have spoken to most of the primary producers in the fine wool industry, in the beef industry and in the rural seed industry, which represents the bulk of agricultural production in my electorate, and I have found that they are not complaining at all but are doing very well. TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has introduced this legislation as a consequence of its incredible decision to sell off part of the farm to try to reinstate financial order from the disaster that it has created since coming to office. The financial disaster has become so evident in the past week that there is no doubt that there is grave concern throughout this nation about the crisis which confronts us. It is coincidental that this legislation is before the House at this time and that in part it deals with the banking system of this country. Perhaps it is also coincidental that only in the past 24 hours the private sector has had to go to extraordinary lengths to save a particular bank from collapse. I put it to the House that the Government will need to quickly assume the responsibility of seeing to it that collapses of that kind cannot occur as they did in 1929-30 and shortly after. Steps were taken in that period of Australia's history to ensure that there was safety in the banking system.

SPEECH.PARA: I am appalled to find that deregulation is removing that protection. I put it to the Government: Is it conscious of the history of the financial collapse of the 1930s, the result of which was positive action by my predecessor, the late Sir Earle Page, to introduce in this House the provision of statutory reserve deposits to ensure that collapses would not occur again as they did at that time? We have seen a weakening of that system, and I will apportion some of the blame to this side of the House as a consequence of deregulation of the financial system in this country. I think we have received a sound warning in the past few days and one that we had better heed quickly or we will see disaster of a kind that none of us could be forgiven for.

I am concerned about the implications of this legislation, and after all it is really only a machinery measure now because of the Government's decision to sell the interest of the Commonwealth of Australia in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA), which was established for a specific purpose. The Government picked the sale of this asset along with a number of others merely as a matter of convenience to meet a budgetary fad, which was to try to put to this Parliament and to the people of this country that it had balanced its Budget. Of course, we all know that that is fictitious. The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) has challenged us tonight to say what we would do, but I point out that that has already been put forward by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) and by member after member on this side of the House-and that is simply that we would not countenance fiddling a Budget in the way that we saw the Budget of August 1987 fiddled.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would sell Telecom.

—The honourable member for McEwen accuses us of a suggestion on the part of some people that the Opposition would sell off some assets, but he should not accuse me because I am opposed to selling Telecom on the basis that the Government proposes to sell it, and that is merely to take the money, clean up on the sale and go on spending. That certainly would not be the policy of people on this side of the House. I return to the legislation that we are considering.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is very unfortunate that people like the honourable member for McEwen can pretend that the activities of PIBA have now been fully taken up by the private banking sector-in other words, he used a specific quote and said that one of the purposes of the bank was to provide refinancing for the rural sector and that was now being taken up by the private banking sector. Of course, the honourable member knows that that is sheer rubbish because it is not being taken up in that way at all.

The tragedy is that, under the mode of deregulation implemented by this Government and talked about by people on both sides of the House, the Government is simply ignoring the history of the financial needs of sectors of the vital productive community of this country-and primary producers certainly constitute one of those important elements. They need a special provision of finance and this measure in part removes that special provision. I think that is tragic.

I have mentioned the risk of weakening the structure of statutory reserve deposit provisions. Of course, it was from statutory reserve deposits that we were able to make special allocation of funds for farm loans schemes even prior to the operation of PIBA. There has been a positive approach to the needs of the farming community. In the last five years, when there has been the most disastrous drought on record, the banking system has not met the needs as might have occurred under the system that operated in earlier years. I think that was a tragedy.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—The honourable member for Mallee has had bitter experience of this, as have other honourable members from areas that were so ravaged by the drought of the last few years. I have no doubt the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) has experienced this. He spoke about the need for recognition of the system that was begun by the previous Government of farmers having the benefit of income equalisation deposits. We cannot have one thing without the other. What is the use of suggesting that the private sector will handle all these needs when the truth is that it does not? I put that to the Government and its supporters who are always so keen to accommodate such propositions as the enormous expansion in this country in recent times of the credit union movement. It was given special privileges so that it might accommodate its supporters. Fair enough; I am not opposed to that. The credit union movement is an established means of finance and special assistance to an enormous number of people employed in industry throughout this country, public servants in particular. If it is good enough for that section of the community to get some specific benefit it is good enough for the primary industry sector to get benefits too. And here we are taking them away and saying, `Ah, deregulation. It is all right, the private banking sector will look after the needs'. The truth is that this means there will be no specific allocation of funds for specific loans for primary production. I wonder whether next we will lose the facility of the Commonwealth Development Bank. If we do, there will be a huge void not only for primary producers but for a vast body of people in the productive sector of this country. At present such people can go to the Commonwealth Development Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today we had a debate about the fishing industry and a Government member said that what fishermen want is a special means of finance: they ought to have their own bank. And here we are an hour and a half later with the Government putting through a measure to take away a specific and positive provision for a sector of the primary producers of this country. A Government member was advocating it; the Government is here taking it away. If that is not folly I do not know what is.

So many needs are being overlooked. The Government is glossing over this. Government supporters find it convenient to talk about the benefits from the rural adjustment scheme, for example. If one is getting a benefit from the rural adjustment scheme it means that one is on one's way out, one is going out of the industry, one is finished. Yet the honourable member for McEwen talked about representing 4,000 farmers in this House. He gets up and extols the rural adjustment scheme as a means of finance. Good heavens, receiving funding under that scheme means that the farmer is on the dole, that he is being paid out. It certainly is not a means of finance for those farmers who want to be effective and productive. Yet he claims that his farmers are in good shape and they have no worries. There cannot be too many of them getting the benefit of the rural adjustment scheme. Probably they do not need it, but that is not to say they do not need the facility of other finance if they are to be effective producers, able to buy equipment, update their property and to be actively cost-effective and produce profitably and to contribute to our exports. Exports from Australia are our only means of saving us from financial disaster in the period immediately ahead. The Government knows it; the Treasurer (Mr Keating) knows it; and the Government's advisers know it. But unfortunately the policies of the Australian Labor Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —What are your policies?

—I made that very clear earlier. The honourable member must be a little deaf or disinclined to hear what our policies are. Specifically, they certainly are not to put up a fake Budget and then to sell off assets to try to balance the books. That is what the measure before the House is proposing, as I said a little earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the importance of specific finance provisions through the banking system, as PIBA was, for the needs of the rural sector of this country. Let us take one area that has been totally neglected-finance for young people to be able to go on the land. There is no adequate provision for that whatsoever. When people are getting on in years and find it difficult to carry on their property they would like their family to take over-for example, a son who has probably been trained, has the capacity, the know-how, the skill, but he needs finance to do it. PIBA was a possible source of finance. There would no doubt be cases to be found on the books of PIBA where a refinance loan had enabled something of that sort to be done. Are we to see the end of it under this new sell-off-the Western Australian bank of something or other has a 17 per cent shareholding? Goodness knows what the policy direction from the Government of Western Australia will be on the continuation of this financial institution, but you can bet your life that it will not be a national outlook; you can bet your life it will be some one-sided proposition that will ignore the real needs and aspirations of those who saw PIBA introduced and put on the statute book. Tonight I lament the fact that we are seeing it lost to the benefit of this nation. It is a tragedy and unfortunately there will have to be many more tragedies before we relearn the lesson of the 1930s and the need for special finance.

My recollection goes back a number of years to my family and the family farm. In 1929 the bank account for that farm happened to be with the State Savings Bank of New South Wales. The doors were closed. There was no more credit. There was no value in what was deposited in the account. The bank was shut down and there was no statutory reserve deposit to carry that bank forward. My parents were lucky enough to hang on to the farm; it was a fairly non-productive farm but at least it was their home. At least it was somewhere that they could cling to until things very slowly recovered. It took about 10 years. During that time-and I still have the records to prove it-there were no private enterprise banks that were prepared to finance that farm-for very simple and understandable reasons. It was not profitable. The advice would have been, `Oh, sell it. Walk off. Forget it'. My parents did not. They stuck with it and I still own it and I am proud of that fact. But I would not own it today if it had not been for finance that came through a banking system largely introduced by my predecessor, Sir Earle Page, to make it possible for farmers to have low interest loans, to have benefits specifically to cope with a difficult period, to cope with floods and droughts and many other things. Here we are tonight removing these measures.

Unfortunately, lessons are learned, then come the good times. Those lessons, and the experience from difficult days, are too easily forgotten. We are seeing this today in stark reality, with this nation facing a financial crisis, with a number of other nations facing a financial crisis and with the world going headlong into a financial crisis. This might not have been happening if we had kept our heads during the boom period and maintained a degree of regulation in the banking and monetary system so that things could not go quite as far as they have.

There is a lot of talk about paper money. It is said that all that will be lost if there is a crash is paper money. What utter humbug! What will be lost is the assets of the productive companies and enterprises of this and other nations. Once they are lost, they take a lot of getting back. It is only through productivity and the selling of commodities that we will reproduce the wealth. The reason is that we have gone too far, that we have accepted the belief that we can shuffle paper money around and still survive without having an adequate counterbalance. Such a counterbalance in the banking system, introduced after 1929-30, was the insistence on adequate statutory reserve deposits so that no bank could face the circumstance that it did not have, well and truly identified, the assets, the hard cash in reserve, to balance what it was lending and what it was committing itself to-to ensure that things did not go wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for PIBA.

—The honourable member should not say that. I just hope that we have not gone too far in the last three or four years. I just hope that what we have been hearing about over the weekend will not be repeated too many times or in too many places. I am sad to find tonight that we are losing from the statute book a piece of legislation that provided the basis for specific lending-a safe basis, with no risk as far as collateral was concerned on either side, on the part of the borrower or the lender. If anything is out of kilter on either side-the borrower or the lender-everyone is in trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the lesson. I hope that those who have said today that we on this side of the House do not have a policy will think hard and long about what they are doing and what their objective is for the immediate future. What we are debating tonight is a fringe matter, but there is something in it that we must recognise. We must not just cast it aside as the easy way to take because the Government decided to cash in on 17 1/2 per cent of the ownership of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall during my contribution tonight answer some of the claims that have been made by the Opposition speakers in this debate, particularly the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson), who preceded me. Let me correct a few of the misapprehensions which have been generated during this debate. The honourable member for Page and Opposition speakers in general have spoken of the merits, it seems, of regulation and of the dangers of deregulation. As I look around the House tonight I see particularly the newly elected honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). I wonder whether he shares the attitudes of other Opposition speakers in this debate about the relative merits of regulation and deregulation. I wonder also what sorts of views the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is not in the House tonight, might express about the merits of regulation and deregulation.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of today's newspapers, ranging from the Australian Financial Review to the Melbourne Age and the Sydney Morning Herald, on the front page or the third page, have run fairly lengthy articles about a biography recently released by Dr Ayres entitled Malcolm Fraser, a political biography. In it Dr Ayres strongly criticises the Treasurer in the Fraser Government, the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), for his regulatory policies. The Australian Financial Review, in its article headed `Biography stirs unresolved rivalries', reports Dr Ayres as having said in his book:
Any notion that John Howard attempted to force the pace of change against Cabinet obstruction is a total misrepresentation of the truth.
That was in reference to progress, pace of change, in deregulation. The Melbourne Age states:

Dr Ayres gives a range of examples where he says Mr Fraser was the driving force towards deregulation. He also accuses Mr Howard of delaying over the terms of reference for the Campbell inquiry into the Australian financial market, and of generally being weak and ineffective in promoting policy for deregulation.

The Leader of the Opposition in the Press today has strenuously denied the claims made in Dr Ayres's book. The Leader of the Opposition is saying today that in fact he is the great deregulator, he was the great deregulator and he will always be the great deregulator-and how dare this man, Dr Ayres, say that he was not? I put it to the House that, if the Leader of the Opposition is correct and he truly is the great deregulator that he believes and claims himself to be, his views are at odds with those of most of the Opposition speakers who have spoken in this debate tonight.

A number of odd claims have been made in this debate tonight. The honourable member for Page held up the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA) as the great save-all for farmers around Australia, wherever they lived and whatever they produced. He saw it as a tragedy that we had sold a 12 1/2 per cent share in this bank. It is not as if we sold a 60 per cent share, an 80 per cent share or every share that the Commonwealth and the States owned in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia: the Commonwealth share of 12 1/2 per cent was realised in June. The honourable member for Page said that was a catastrophe, a tragedy, for the rural sector. The 1987 annual report of the Primary Industry Bank says on page 2:
The Bank's net profit for the year under review, after provision of tax amounting to $3.9 million, was $4.25 million.
The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) will be interested in this:
This represents an increase of some 22.5 per cent over the preceding financial year.

That is not bad. This is the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, the bank that the Opposition is holding up as the great saviour for farmers around Australia, the bank that is providing cheap loans to help out farmers in a crisis. It made a 22 1/2 per cent increase in profit from one year to the other. It is either an extraordinarily efficient bank or it is doing pretty well out of selling loans to farmers. I suspect that it is doing pretty well out of selling loans to farmers.

When this Government came to office after the highly regulated years of the Fraser-Howard Government, we had a banking system which was an oligopoly, which was highly protected, which had among the world's banking systems perhaps the largest gaps or margins between money borrowed and money lent and which was more profitable than any comparable banking system in the Western world. This Government took steps to open up that banking system to more competition. We did that because we wanted to give Australian consumers, Australian business people and Australian farmers a more efficient financial system that would be able to provide loans at the least possible cost. That has been the objective of deregulation. I can assure honourable members that it is not a philosophical or ideological bent that this Government has; it is in the interests of improving efficiency that, where necessary, we are prepared to take the hard decisions and break down some of the regulatory barriers. In the case of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, we realised our 12 1/2 per cent share. We sold it to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia for $2 1/2m. There are a number of conditions under which we sold it. If honourable members opposite bothered to read those conditions they would see that the interests of people in the primary sector, by and large, have been looked after. They include the conditions that the bank be maintained as a separate and ongoing entity, that the bank continue to provide a refinance facility to the rural sector, that 50 per cent of total Primary Industry Bank of Australia loans be directed towards borrowers in the rural sector, that the bank continue to offer-this is important-bill finance at relatively low interest rates and, finally, that two directors to serve on the PIBA board be appointed in consultation with the Commonwealth to represent rural interests. One can hardly say that we have just realised our obligation to this bank, that we have washed our hands of it and have let the Rural Bank, the Primary Industry Bank and all the farmers around Australia sink into the quagmire. Quite the contrary; we have done the right thing by the banking sector in total. In a deregulated financial environment it is no longer appropriate that we hold a 12 1/2 per cent share in the Primary Industry Bank, so we have realised that share and we have built protections into it to safeguard the interests of the rural sector.

I come to a few other points that were made by Opposition speakers. The honourable member for Page attempted to argue-National Party of Australia speakers have put this many times to the House-that the only real wealth produced in Australia and around the world came out of the ground, that unless we get back to producing more wealth, as he put it, which is stuff that you dig out of the ground, the world will go down the drain.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the old mercantilists.

—The honourable member for Charlton, who is a prominent, noted academic and economist, says that they are the old mercantilists. We gave that theory away 150 years ago because we did not think that it worked or was appropriate. All wealth does not come from what we dig up out of the ground. I will give an example. Members of the Opposition might do well to read this week's Time magazine, which I read on an Australian Airlines flight to Canberra, about the resurgence of profitability in the primary sector. The article referred particularly to the wool industry. It referred to what we are doing and the record prices which we are receiving for fine wool. The article made the point that research and development has paid off in that industry. It is a fine example to other industries around Australia, because the wool industry has always made enormous investments in research and development. There is now a wool boom which is qualitatively and quantitatively different from previous wool booms because world stockpiles of wool are at an all time low. Yet the price we are getting for wool is excellent. The article mentioned one of Australia's best fine wool merino studs. It is a stud that produces 16 micron wool and under. As the honourable member for Charlton would know, that is extremely fine wool. The wool is so good that it received the world record price last year of $280 a kilogram. Can honourable members believe that a merino sheep which has been on the high plains in a blue cloth all year and is shorn expertly fetches a price of $280 a kilo? That sheep probably produces five kilos of wool. So one sheep produces over $1,000 worth of wool.

SPEECH.PARA: That sounds like an enormous return on investment. It is a very good return on investment, but the point of the article and the point I am about to make is that the President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Ian McLachlan, said that, while that is a great return to get off the sheep's back, so to speak, for every $280 we get for a kilo of wool we sell it to an Italian suitmaker who adds a value not just of another $280 but 10 times the raw value of the fleece. So we come to the question of where wealth is created. It is true that some wealth is created on the sheep's back-$280 worth of wealth-but $2,800 is created by the Italian suitmaker who weaves that cloth, adds value to it and puts it in a high quality suit that is sold among the best clothing retailers in the world. The production of wealth is not just a question of growing a product on a sheep's back; the production of wealth is adding value. I see that the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) is in the House tonight. He has just returned from another of his trips overseas during which he has put the interests of Australian and indeed world producers in terms of a fairer world trade system. The Minister is wearing an Australian pure wool suit. I do not know where the suit was made. Whether it was made overseas or in Australia-I am sure that it was made in Australia-the point remains that the wool that went into it probably represents about 10 per cent of the total retail value of that suit. If his suit is worth $400, the wool is worth $40 at most and the rest is value added.

In terms of the crisis which is occurring in world trading markets, from Australia's point of view it is a crisis which has been brought about, in part, because for many years under the policies of the Opposition parties we put too many of our production eggs in one basket. That is not to demean in any way the enormous importance of our primary industries and commodities to Australia. Our primary industries alone account for nearly 40 per cent of our total exports. In terms of the concept of creating wealth and adding value, it is the newly industrialised countries around the world-some of the Pacific rim countries; Korea and so on-which in the last two decades have been adding value to manufactured products, which have been the fastest growing areas of world trade. Poor old Australia!

Until this Government came to office in 1983 and floated the dollar, deregulated the financial markets and put in place assistance and incentives for secondary industry, we in Australia did nothing about it. We now see that the strategy introduced by this Government is starting to pay results. As the Minister for Trade Negotiations would know, in the last 12 months in Australia we have seen a 50 per cent increase in the value of certain types of manufactured exports from Australia. Admittedly, that is of a low base, but it is a very substantial improvement. We are adding value. I would challenge the honourable member for Page and any other of his National Party colleagues to debate in this House with me and to challenge the assumption that those exports of valued added manufactures is not generating wealth for Australia. Of course they are generating wealth for Australia. In exactly the same way as gold mining, wheat production and wool production add wealth for Australia so too does adding value to those products, other manufactures and high technology goods create wealth for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it does.

—The honourable member is at variance with his colleague the honourable member for Page, who only 20 minutes ago berated honourable members by saying that the only real wealth was something that grew out of the ground. That is nonsense. I have totally destroyed his simplistic argument. It is total nonsense.
