SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on the Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill 1987. Before I refer directly to the Bill, I pick up some of the nonsense that has been espoused by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby). I have one thing in common with the honourable member-that is, I entered this House on the same day as he did. Ever since I entered this House 4 1/2 years ago, I have listened to honourable members opposite peddle deceptive statements about where the Opposition stands. They have peddled them so often that they believe them and hope that the rest of Australia will believe them. It started with a deceptive statement about the so-called deficit. Honourable members opposite peddled a $9.6 billion figure so often that, quite frankly, it began to be believed not only by them but by the nation. Tonight the honourable member for Bendigo again peddled the nonsense that the Opposition has no policies. We went to the last election with policies, but the honourable member still continues to peddle this deceptive line, hoping that eventually the whole of Australia will believe it. You know, Mr Deputy Speaker-every member on this side knows-that we had policies, but that the real issue is that we are the Opposition and the obligation from a policy point of view rests squarely with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, the honourable member for Bendigo had the absolute gall to talk to us about deregulation. He had the absolute gall to peddle some sort of economic nonsense by telling us that wool on the sheep's back is worth so much money, and it is worth 10 times as much when it is on a person's back. I happen to know that the whole objective of what we in the Opposition are about from the point of view of deregulation is ensuring that the suit that he referred to as being worn by the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) is made not in Italy but in Australia. Why is it not made in Australia? It is because the deregulation that we would fervently pursue would move into a deregulation of the wages area. It is the regulation of our wages market that has ensured that that wool is not converted into a suit in Australia. Let the honourable member for Bendigo run sincerely down the deregulation path. Let him grasp the nettle of the deregulation of our wages market, and then let us see how sincere the remarks he has aired in the House this evening are.

We all know that there is nothing more important to Australia's future than the cultivation of high technology industries. We all know what value added manufacturing is all about. We will support the Government in the efforts that it makes to attract manufacturing industry to Australia. Quite frankly, I have stood in this House on a number of occasions, as I do tonight, to welcome the legislation that is being debated, but very rarely have I heard the same sort of charitable instinct espoused by the honourable member for Bendigo. Very rarely has the same sort of embrace of the responsible stand taken by the Opposition been made by the honourable member. I have just about had enough of being misrepresented conveniently by the honourable member for Bendigo and his ilk.

On 30 June this year that portion of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA) that the Commonwealth held was sold to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia. As a result of that action, $2.5m was generated and poured into the public coffers. As I have said to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Opposition does not oppose this legislation or this action. In fact, there has been very little reaction across Australia to this sale because the Primary Industry Bank of Australia had largely begun to fulfil a role that was already being occupied by the other banks. The honourable member for Bendigo has made the point that the existence of PIBA meant that the other banks were forced to become marginally more competitive and that deregulation of the banking industry brought a measure of new life into the banking industry in Australia. We on this side of the House have welcomed that deregulation.

Prior to the acquisition of PIBA by the Commonwealth, four major trading banks and one consortium of four State banks each held a 17 1/2 per cent share in PIBA and the Commonwealth held a 12 1/2 per cent share. That 12 1/2 per cent share, as I said earlier, has now been sold to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia. This new concept of PIBA was granted a banking authority on 30 June 1987 and the former PIBA Act of 1977 has been made redundant. The legislation we are debating tonight repeals and makes consequential amendments to the Primary Industry Bank Act to allow those events that took place on 30 June to be legalised.

I want to refer to the importance of agriculture in Australia and to the importance of the Primary Industry Bank in the agricultural setup. I quote from a speech made by Dr Andy Stoeckel, who was once known as the chief economist of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and is now a director with the Centre for International Economics. At the United Farmers and Stockowners Conference in South Australia on Tuesday, 28 July this year Dr Stoeckel said:
Australia's net external debt position is already high-it is expected to be around $90 billion or some 36 per cent of GDP by mid June 1987.

In the debate on the matter of public importance today the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said that our external debts had risen above that 36 per cent to almost 40 per cent. Dr Stoeckel went on to say:

Australia is now one of the highest debtor nations in the world. It ranks amongst many of the Third World economies. Moreover, the position is deteriorating. An enormous trade turn-around is required just to stop the debt burden growing and to stabilise the already high net debt position by 1990. A stabilised external debt position relative to GDP is a minimum requirement for balanced growth.

This point was taken up earlier in the debate by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) who pointed out that we have some cause for concern about where our total financial system, including the Rural Industries Bank of Western Australia, is heading when we look at the sort of debt we are endeavouring to service as a nation and when we look at our September balance of payments deficit of a record September figure of $1.35 billion. Dr Stoeckel went on to say:
The dimension of the problem is illustrated by the fact that to prevent Australia's net external debt position from deteriorating further--
deteriorating, mark you-

Our trade balance would need to improve by up to $15 billion. To put this in perspective, exports of rural origin, which account for 36 per cent of Australian merchandise exports were $11.6 billion in 1985-86. Thus to achieve a trade turn-around of $15 billion would be a major task. It would require us to improve the world trading system, to restructure the Australian economy and to remove anti-trade policies. Right away, one point should be stressed. Artificially encouraging particular export sectors, such as manufacturing exports is not the solution. Australian industry policy should be one of a `level playing field' where private incentives and neutral policies determine the composition of Australian industry.
The legislation before the House is a step towards having a level playing field. Dr Stoeckel also went on to say:
. . . to prevent Australia's net external debt position from deteriorating further-
not to improve the position-
our trade balance would need to improve by up to $15 billion.

To put this in perspective, this would mean that policies would have to change to allow us to improve the performance of our rural exports. Dr Stoeckel suggested a few points. He said that to improve our balance of trade by $1 billion would require a 9 per cent increase in world agricultural prices, or an 80 per cent cut in tariffs, or a one per cent cut in the cost of wages, or a one per cent cut in real government spending, or alternatively, a restructuring of some of our taxes. Much of what we need as a nation depends on our capacity in the rural sector to perform and on the capacity of the rural sector to have available to it the money it needs to borrow in a flexible context. There would not be anyone with an agricultural background on this side of the House who has not had need of, if not access to, the sorts of facilities that PIBA once offered and that we on this side of the House would hope the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia will continue to offer.

I have in property restructuring, as I know you have, Mr Deputy Speaker, had need of some form of flexible loan. There would not be a property developer in the rural sense, in the agricultural sense, on this side of the House who had not at some time been embarrassed by the demand he had for borrowings in order to produce a more efficient property. You know, Mr Deputy Speaker, as I do, that whether one chooses to clear a property, whether one chooses to improve one's irrigation techniques, whether one chooses to improve one's cropping techniques, whether one chooses to step into the all important area of water storage, whether one is forced to retain some of one's progeny in order to have herd and flock buildup in the interests of increasing stock numbers, whether one is in horticultural industries and part of a property rebuild that involves long lead times before that property is in production, whether one is obliged to hang on to livestock beyond the point at which the bank forces one to sell it in order to get a better price, it is very important to have flexibility in rural marketing. It is this flexibility that the Primary Industry Bank of Australia offered. It is this flexibility that the Commonwealth Development Bank, through its rural sector, has offered in the past, and it is this flexibility that tonight we in the Opposition would say we seek to ensure is still offered by the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia as it takes over the role of the old PIBA. Contrary to the remarks made by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby)--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are all closet socialists.

—And contrary to the interjection that just occurred, this side of the House is not opposing this legislation but is saying that PIBA has played an important role and one that we hope the banking sector will continue to make available.

SPEECH.PARA: In preparation for this debate I spoke to the National Farmers Federation (NFF) and I discovered that far from its being pleased about this legislation, as was implied by an honourable member opposite a little earlier, it does have some concerns. Its concern is not with the sale of the bank, it is not with the principle that on this side of the House we have largely been prepared to embrace; its concern is that it notes that loans that were once available to primary producers are now to be available to the rural sector. The NFF said to me, `If you are standing in this debate make the point that we would like to ensure that the allocation of funds that was once available to primary producers ought to continue to be available to primary producers'. They said that if that allocation is made merely to the rural sector it will be possible to find those funds soaked up in one or two major projects such as, as honourable members could imagine, new bulk handling facilities, new grain loading terminals at a port, a new abattoir or-

TALK.START.PARA: —Or another Ord River.

—Or, as the honourable member for Curtin, in his knowledgeable way points out, heaven forbid, another Ord River scheme. The NFF had one other area of concern. Its first concern was that there ought not to be a focus on the rural sector in place of the primary producer. Its second concern was that the tenders that were out for the sale of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia were out for such a short time and there was so little publicity surrounding it. They simply seek an assurance that other interested parties who might have sought to tender for the work formerly done by the Primary Industry Bank of Australia were not locked out of the tendering process. I seek the Minister's comment on that. For example, the NFF asked: `Were groups such as Elders, Dalgetys, or the Wheat Board given a similar chance to competitively bid for the work of PIBA along with the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia?'. We can be sure that particular groups such as Dalgetys, Elders and, I guess it would be fair to say, the Wheat Board, have across Australia a network that would facilitate banking that would rival anything that the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia could offer.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bendigo, in his criticism of the Opposition, accused the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) of suggesting that prosperity only resulted from digging holes in the ground. The gall of the man! We represent primary producers. Primary producers do not represent holes in the ground but Australia's finest renewable resource. We want to ensure that the flexible banking facilities that farmers and primary producers need in order to maintain their role in producing export income out of Australia's finest renewable resource is not, in any way, disadvantaged by the sale of PIBA to the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia. It is no news to this House that primary producers have lived through difficult times during the life of this Government, which is not entirely the fault of this Government. It is a sobering factor to realise that many of these difficult times have not been climatically generated for we have not had the nationwide drought that the Fraser Administration had to contend with. But in spite of good seasons we have primary producers who, until eight months ago, were right down on their luck.

It has been easy for members opposite to say-we have heard it in this debate tonight-that the circle has gone right around and all is well for primary industry, that wool is booming and grain industries are looking brighter. I am sorry, but that is arrant nonsense. In the Adelaide Advertiser, the South Australian newspaper, of last week, the United Farmers and Stock- owners of South Australia Inc. was bemoaning the tragedy facing South Australian producers as a result of drought, hail and frost. It is simply not good enough to presume that Australia's rural industry has gone full circle and all is well. The nationwide drought that so plagued the Fraser Administration has not recurred and, on the law of averages, is just around the corner.

The honourable member for Wannon has made a very eloquent call for the reintroduction of income equalisation deposits which would allow farmers to be more prudent in their preparation and to be independent of government in the face of drought. This Government has done nothing about making that sort of facility available. What we are debating tonight is the change of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia from its independent identity to a group encompassed in the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia. We do not oppose that, but we do seek to get some assurance that what the Government is doing as a result of selling its share in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia will not disadvantage primary producers.

I note that the Government sought to ensure that two of the directors of the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia and its new PIBA arm would have a rural background and I note, as I run my eye through the incoming bank board that two men, namely, Mr Davidson and Mr Smart, have been appointed to these positions to represent Australia's rural interests. I wish them well, for Australia's rural community cannot afford to be ignored by any one of the banking interests in this nation and the flexibility in banking that is so essential to rural prosperity must be maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that in the chamber tonight are two people who were instrumental in the setting up of the original Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA). I refer firstly to the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson). I recall when I first came here that at one of my first Party meetings he, with great fervour, advocated the setting up of a bank for primary producers. I think it is fitting tonight that he was able to give sound, constructive suggestions.

SPEECH.PARA: Additionally, I recall going to the Huon Valley in Tasmania in about 1976 when the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), in his usual inimitable fashion, was indicating that the apple growers of that part of Tasmania were in a particularly difficult position. He invited us down there and he repeated the aspirations of the honourable member for Page at a big meeting. I think it is fitting that the honourable member for Page participated in this debate and that the honourable member for Franklin is taking a keen, intelligent interest in the debate. He has been here for almost the total debate. Following that era the then Minister for Primary Industry, the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, appointed a sub-committee consisting of Senator Jim Short and Mr Geoff Giles who, at one time, was the honourable member for Angas and at another time the honourable member for Wakefield. It is fitting and proper too that the present honourable member for Wakefield, who followed him, participated in that debate. I was also a member of the sub-committee set up to talk with farmers and industry generally. It would be fair to say that the history books will record that our initial ideas were taken up by the Cabinet and reflected in the legislation.

I want to take a few minutes to pay tribute to PIBA for what it has achieved. We must, at all times, be aware of the effect that the repealing of this 1977 Bill will have on the farming communities. I think it is fit and proper in a debate which is closing a chapter to recall with pride some of the many splendid achievements of PIBA and its contribution to Australia's important agricultural sector. It had a great reputation. It was able to attract deposits from investors both within Australia and overseas.

I recall talking to Mr John Frearson. He indicated to me that the ordinary housewives in places such as Holland and Belgium were going into the post offices and taking up the offer of deposits in PIBA. That just indicates the fact that it was well known in Australia and it was also well known overseas. It is pleasing to note that the funds that they were able to generate were subsequently distributed, as the honourable member for Page said, in the form of loans across a wide geographic spread through the branch networks of its shareholder banks and, of course, the major pastoral houses.

The idea of establishing a national rural lending institution evolved as an extension of the belief that the agricultural sector would be better served by a bank which could ensure continuity of supply in conditions which were economically suited to the capital intensive nature of agriculture. There was a recognised need for a lending institution which was able to cater to the needs of the relatively small size of most farm businesses which were experiencing difficulties in securing equity finance for expansion and development.

I would like to take this opportunity of applauding the Fraser Government on opening its eyes to the needs of the agricultural community in the late 1970s and, most importantly, for acting on those needs with the provisions of PIBA. The Fraser Government showed courage in effectively recognising, what is now a universally accepted fact; that is, an efficient system of rural credit is an essential part of the machinery required for the economic development of agricultural resources and the promotion of efficiency in production. PIBA is, above all, Australian in theme and substance, based on the philosophy which usefully intermingles the celebration of free enterprise with the spirit of the Aussie battler. Robert Perrier, Australian dramatist, restated this ethos in respect of the theatre when he said:
If theatre is to contribute in a meaningful way to our culture, it has to connect to the unique style and spirit of Australia and with the felt life of its people.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I suggest to you that within this sphere of primary industry, PIBA also adopted this philosophy which it has kept at the heart of its operations during the past 10 years. From PIBA's incorporation on 21 July 1978, it recognised that the agricultural sector was, indeed, the most important single source of export earnings and therefore set as its broad national objective an assurance that long term credit would be available to agriculture on terms broadly comparable with those on which it is available to other major industries. This philosophy emanated from the bank's desire to dedicate itself to rescuing the agricultural sector from a certain demise by restructuring the banking policies held by other lending institutions at that time.

It is interesting to note that in the first two weeks of lending, the bank's approvals amounted to about $10m. Although for some time there had been demands from primary producers for greater access to long term funds and for concessional interest rates, those demands became more claimant during the rural depression of 1969 to 1972. Indeed, Hansard seems to point to the view that, had not the McMahon Government been defeated in the Federal election in December 1972, primary producer pressure might possibly have led to the establishment of some kind of national rural bank earlier than 1978. Newcomers to this Parliament from the present Government party try to indicate that they are concerned about primary industries, but I do not want to debate that issue because it is not necessary to recall, even to their biased minds, that from 1972 to 1975, Australian primary industry had to deal with sledgehammer blows like `You've never had it so good' from Ministers when all the farmers were doing was rapidly going broke.

The initial years of rural depression sparked the move of both life assurance companies and pastoral finance companies to reduce their rural lending. Thus, rural producers were confronted with simultaneous limitations to two of their important traditional sources of credit. Notwithstanding the steadily growing activities of lending institutions such as the Commonwealth Development Bank and schemes such as the rural adjustment scheme, pressure on the Commonwealth Government for still further access to long term funds became heavy. During this poor rural economic period, however, the bulk of rural lending by the trading banks was directed primarily to the provision of seasonal finance. There was not finance available on a long term planning basis. This restriction was further frustrated by the banks' imposition of restraints on the total volume of their lending. Faced with their overriding responsibility to maintain sufficient liquidity to cope with a wide range of possible community demands, banks were forced to make the move into longer term lending, albeit gradually. This was a matter of sheer necessity when producers found themselves in financial difficulties. In many cases, if they sold up, the banks would not have got enough money to pay off the mortgage. Obviously, it was good business to keep the farmers in a producing situation, for history records that many farmers were able to trade out of their difficulties and become viable propositions once again.

I was interested in the remarks of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I would just like him to know that Australia is a pretty big place and does not begin and end in South Australia. In that beautiful bit of heaven that fell from out of the sky, the Darling Downs, we have had a drought for two years. It is the first drought in 200 years. When widespread drought or lengthy periods of low prices came about, banks and financial institutions were often confronted with a hard choice between demanding that the property be sold at a sacrificial price or carrying the producer until seasons and prices improved. It could be very difficult to judge whether it was prudent to encourage producers who were in financial difficulties to remain on their properties until conditions became more favourable.

These hardships suffered by farming producers, coupled with insufficient means of acquiring funds to cope with these difficulties, invoked a do or die situation. Unless finance was to be made available to primary producers, the industry was doomed to collapse and so the PIBA was set to play a crucial and pivotal role in rectifying the situation. Initially, the bank's approvals in the first two weeks amounted to $10m. I believe that it is appropriate, when we see the changing format of the Primary Industry Bank, to pay tribute to people like Walter Ives who was Chairman from 1978 to 1987. He was a distinguished Australian and a world authority, highly regarded as an administrator and a practical person. Above all, Walter Ives was a truly courteous gentleman, ever ready and willing to help members of parliament, both in his senior position in the Public Service and, quite obviously, in his challenging position as first Chairman of the PIBA.

John Frearson is a household name in Australian agriculture and one of the few people to have become a legend in his lifetime. He has been not only general manager, director, managing director and now deputy chairman, but also plays an integral part in bringing in financial expertise to such huge operations as the Australian Wheat Board. We salute those two people and others who have laboured in the Primary Industry Bank. I know that, while they look forward to the challenges of the future, they will be wiping a furtive tear from their eye when they note that this legislation dismantling PIBA finally gets through Parliament.

Like the member for Page, I express the hope that, 10 years hence, primary producers will be getting the same sort of service from the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia that was given by those in PIBA. I understand, although I am not from Western Australia, that the R and I Bank has a proven track record in that State with in excess of 100 branches, including sub-branches. However, there is only a single branch in Sydney and sub-branches in Brisbane and Melbourne to cater for all the eastern States. Now the banks and pastoral houses share will no longer be present, and one wonders whether Western Australia, with a huge branch network, will have a better service than the farmers in the eastern States. I hope that the eastern Australian farmers will not be disadvantaged because of the huge branch structure in Western Australia. Surely, the primary producers in eastern States have the right to expect the same service that their Western Australian colleagues are enjoying.

It is imperative that the R and I Bank upholds this challenge, particularly in the light of the fact that the agricultural sector is once again in a state of rapid decline. This has been stimulated by chronic drought conditions in certain areas, about which I have spoken, which have forced many farmers into the groping talons of bankruptcy. Across the board, on a national scale, the economic trend has been gravitating towards higher debts and lower incomes. These are facts of life. According to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the average farm business debt per farm has grown from $58,189 in 1983-84 to $74,000 in 1986-87. That is basically an impossible situation for farmers when it is coupled with their share of the record overseas debt inflicted on us by the Hawke-Keating Government. This has happened while the average farm income on farms has declined from $23,187 to a mere $16,400. I hope that those who sit opposite will show some enthusiasm for ensuring that the farmers of Australia get reasonable incomes, just as they show such enthusiasm for being followers of people like Kelty, Crean and, I suspect, that fellow Norm Gallagher, who claims to be the friend of many of the people who sit opposite.

These statistics serve to illustrate the current poor state of primary industry within Australia. However, this picture is made even more depressing when examined in terms of individual primary industry sectors. Let me paint the gloomy picture, highlighting just a few of the problem areas. The average income of family farms in the four horticultural industries surveyed by the Bureau is expected to decline by 46 per cent in 1986-87. Within this sector, the average income of family farms in the citrus industry fell from $16,800 in 1985-86 to a paltry $3,900 in 1986-87. We never hear members opposite talk about the poor citrus farmers of Australia. This fall resulted mainly from a 14 per cent decline in total cash receipts while cash costs, as they always do under socialists, failed to fall.

The rice industry is affected equally seriously. Average incomes in family farms in the New South Wales rice industry are expected to bottom out this year at minus $3,200. This is down from last year's income of $13,600. The main factors causing a decline in incomes are lower export returns and rising costs. The people opposite do not seem to be able to understand this. They are always keen to jack up costs, improve wages, et cetera, but they never take into account productivity or what one gets from one's products on world markets over which one has absolutely no control.

As a final example, in my State of Queensland continuing drought conditions have contributed to another year of poor yields for sugar farmers in its north and south regions. Average farm incomes are expected to be around minus $6,000 this year. In addition to this, more than half of the farmers are expected to have not very good prospects for the following year. So we are faced with a situation of crisis proportions: drought conditions contributing to poor yields for farmers, forcing the low prices being received for their produce, and further exacerbated by ever-increasing financial overheads.

Clearly then, on a larger canvas, we are confronted with a situation which has the potential to herald the decline and ultimate destruction of primary industry within Australia. That is what the honourable member for Page was concerned about. He pointed that out to the Government. On the basis of this bleak outlook, the Government has an obligation to take some positive action in order to alleviate the crisis situation. After all, our future is in the hands of the farmers. It appears, however, that the decline of primary industry has been orchestrated by a group of armchair economists who have failed to consider the practicalities of this situation. They expect Australia's primary producers to be competitive in a world market but, at the same time, are `leg-roping' the producers by placing trade and tariff burdens on them. It is high time the economists controlling our nation reassessed their priorities in line for the betterment of Australia.

In 1987 the contribution of primary industry to Australian export wealth was roughly 20 per cent. In monetary terms, it earned a massive $6 billion. In the light of this pronouncement, I would like to add my voice to the support of the President of the National Farmers Federation, Ian McLachlan, for the commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations in Geneva last week. The Prime Minister finally recognised that the increasing burdens being placed on primary producers in the form of import protection measures, including tariff quotas, licensing and embargoes, were bringing the industry to its knees. This decision to free up trade and to make cost imputs to farmers cheap effectively means that subsidies to farmers would no longer be needed to counteract the aforementioned burdens. This would save Australia a huge $1 billion per year. The President of the National Farmers Federation agreed with that point of view.

It is clear, then, that primary producers are not after handouts. Rather, what they stand for encapsulates the spirit of free enterprise. History has shown us that they are willing to face hardships and take financial risks in order to achieve their goals. What they do not expect, however, is to be `hobbled' by the Government amidst their efforts to achieve these goals. It is my belief that the Rural and Industries Bank, in seeking to operate as a vehicle of sectoral assistance, will help to facilitate these goals. In the light of this pronouncement then-and I regret the demise of the Primary Industry Bank-the National Party supports this legislation. We hope that the past achievements of the Primary Industry Bank will be the stepping stone to greater achievements in the future by the R and I Bank.

I am fascinated when I look at what has been done, not only in relation to the Primary Industry Bank of Australia but, more recently, in relation to a number of the other assets that this Government wants to sell. It does not seem to me that the Government is particularly interested in promoting competition, improving efficiency or introducing market discipline. As far as I can see, the Government's primary motivation is just the dollars-the bottom line, the dollars that it seeks in order to pull its Budget back to what it calls balance in the current fiscal year; $1 billion this year and a foreshadowing of $1 billion next year. As I say, there is no motivation to improve efficiency, to introduce market discipline or to promote competition.

One of the best examples of this at present is what is happening in relation to the sale of part of one of our assets-our embassy in Tokyo. Here the motivation seems entirely to be to get about $500m or $600m as fast as possible in the current financial year. It has very little to do with what is an appropriate representation of this Government and this country in one of our most important trading nations. It is an embarrassment to one like me who has spent a lot of time in Japan speaking with Japanese at all levels that we have the situation where our Government has really forced the pace just, as I say, to get dollars out of that operation with no particular motivation to improve our representation.

The fact that we have a foreign affairs representation, a trade policy representation and an Austrade representation does not seem to be part of the whole issue of the rationalisation of our presence in Tokyo. In fact, we seem to have forced the pace in the way that we have approached the issue. In particular, we seem to have forced the pace in terms of the tendering process that has been adopted. It seems to me that if we were genuinely interested in doing a sensible job in rationalising our presence in Japan, the Government would have taken quite a different tack. The bottom line, as I said before, is simply the motivation of the dollar-more dollars into the kitty, make the Budget look better than it really is and hopefully forestall the sort of criticism that would otherwise come. We can pull that bluff on financial markets only for a certain time. They ultimately vote with their feet, as they will in the case of this Budget.

If the Government is serious about privatisation, I think it should realistically respond more substantively to the challenge that is before it. It is no use paying lip service to that concept, it is no use focusing on one aspect of that concept, because there are a number of key aspects of privatisation that we hear nothing about from this Government. As I said, the Government's focus is almost entirely on the selling of assets in order to get a few dollars into the kitty in the space of particular financial year. But if the Government were serious about privatisation it would broaden the concept. For example, the Government should take a long, hard look at the possibility of contracting out a whole range of government services that are presently provided in the private sector, quite often at a lower cost and certainly, in most cases, much more efficiently than is currently the case by government. It is interesting that that dimension of privatisation has not received much attention under this Government; yet it seems to be one of the most potentially productive areas in the debate about privatisation. One can go through a whole range of government activities, including the meal and linen services in hospitals, car services, printing services, courier services, and so on. Many of those services are already available in the private sector and, as I say, they are more efficiently provided at a lower cost, but they are not getting the attention they deserve.

Other countries take the situation quite a lot further and even things like the administration of prisons are matters for private sector management. It is a question of introducing competition in some cases or improving efficiency in the processes of government much more significantly than the Government is prepared to do. It should give that concept the hearing that it deserves. Obviously the Government is trying to do what it can in regard to privatisation without offending to a significant extent its main political power base-the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). It is interesting that, while there has been a quick grab for dollars in an unexpected way in the mini-Budget and again in the official Budget this year, since then the Government seems to have run into quite a bit of trouble in terms of marketing those ideas within its political power base and in convincing the ACTU that it is in fact a worthwhile endeavour.

Perhaps most interesting of all through all this process is the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has gone strangely quiet on the issue of privatisation as he more than anyone else desperately needs the revenue that will come from the asset sale that he has focused on to date. He must get this revenue because clearly his revenue base will dwindle as a result of the effects of the recent stock market collapse. There is also the fact that the crude oil levy is to fade out in its significance in the course of the next couple of years, and the Treasurer recognises that a large part of this year's so-called Budget balance is due to the one-off nature of a number of those key revenue items.

In particular, the profitability of the Reserve Bank of Australia in recent years, which has kicked about $2.6 billion into government coffers, is unlikely to be repeated in future years. In fact, if one reads the most recent annual report of the Reserve Bank, one sees two explicit qualifications. First, there is a suggestion that the valuation of the Reserve Bank's books today does not allow the possibility of further substantial one-off revenue gains of that sort because all the opportunities for the Reserve Bank to make money in the way it has in the past-acquiring Australian dollars at, say, 57c and selling them back somewhere in the low 70c range-have now gone.

Secondly, the Reserve Bank has warned that it does not intend to be as active in the foreign exchange market, by way of intervention, as it has been in the last 12 or 18 months. If one looks only at the data of the extent of the Reserve Bank intervention over that period, one can only be staggered at how quickly it was forced to move away from what otherwise had been a reasonably free float in the first 12 months of the period of the floating exchange rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now a dirty float.

—Yes, it is now very much a dirty or almost totally fixed float, and I would suggest that it is substantially at the direction of the Government. The Treasurer recognises that that particular revenue source will therefore dwindle in significance as time goes on and he will need to supplement his revenue from that source. According to the Treasurer's own estimates, he will have to forgo some of the revenue that he had hoped to raise, although it is difficult to see how much revenue he would have raised from the identification card that the Government wanted to introduce. The overriding significant economic or fiscal problem at the present time relates to restraint on government expenditure and in fact the challenge to bring about a significant reduction in the size of government and the extent of government expenditure, and privatisation in no way can be seen as a substitute for that. It is important that these two operations be kept quite separate. Do not get me wrong because I, for one, have no particular qualms about selling a lot of existing government assets, and there is a long way to go in that respect. However, the Government should not allow those proceeds to be used as if they were a substitute for the otherwise important restraint on government expenditure. I guess the challenge to the Government should be that the proceeds of those asset sales be set aside for the benefit of future generations, and perhaps in particular they should be used to retire debt.

The Treasurer in his Budget Speech perpetuated the illusion that he is indeed retiring debt. Honourable members may recall that in that speech the Treasurer said that he would retire $1 billion worth of domestic debt and $1 billion worth of overseas debt. It is very difficult to make that link, even for some of my first and second year university students, in the context of a balanced Budget. How is it possible that the Treasurer can retire debt while he is running a balanced Budget? The answer is that he is not actually retiring debt at all because the truth is that last year he borrowed about $1 billion too much-he overborrowed to the extent of about $1 billion. That money went into the Government's cash balances, which are now being run down in order to effectively reduce the size of new overseas debts. So the domestic debt is not really being replaced at all because, if honourable members read the Treasurer's accompanying Budget statements, they will see that he is substituting treasury notes for treasury bonds. So he certainly is retiring, if you like, $1 billion worth of domestic bonds but he is replacing them with shorter dated Treasury notes, so the illusion is complete. There is no retirement of net debt and in fact debt will not be retired in this country until we make significant inroads into Government expenditure, until he addresses the real fiscal policy issue at present; that is, how to restrain government expenditure.

The Opposition has gone to great lengths in recent months to explain not only the significance of that task but also to make a number of fundamental suggestions as to how it might be achieved. The Treasurer would do well to listen to those suggestions and to embark on the process rather than simply fiddle the books; that is, selling off assets and treating them as if they are reductions in expenditure. The challenge to the Treasurer is that he take the proceeds of those asset sales and actually use them to retire debt rather than perpetuate the illusion as he has done. Our domestic and international debts in particular will not stabilise, even on the Government's most optimistic assumptions, until the early 1990s. More realistic assumptions would probably put it in the late 1990s or early 2000s before our international debt situation will actually stabilise and we will have a possibility to reduce that indebtedness. That is a pretty daunting prospect for Australians, and indeed for the children of most existing Australians. We see in this Primary Industry Bank Repeal Bill an early stage in the Government's process of privatisation and an important initial step in the process of fiscal reform. But that is not as far as it should go; the Government has a very long way to go if it is seriously to embark on a process of privatisation and indeed if it is to face up to the realistic and important fiscal policy challenges that are before it today.

In the last couple of days in the House I have been fascinated that the Treasurer could come in here and make light of suggestions of that sort; that he really does not need to adjust his policy stance, he does not need to change his forecast. Madam Speaker, I can assure you that financial markets have a way of getting the attention of even the world's greatest Treasurer and I suggest that that will happen somewhat quicker than he imagines to be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to add a few words to the many tributes that have been made to the late Sir Keith Wilson, who died several weeks ago. Sir Keith's contribution to Federal politics as both a senator for South Australia and as member for Sturt are well known, as are his contributions to public life and to the South Australian community. The simple fact that he was, over time, either President or Chairman of Aged Cottage Homes, the War Blinded Welfare Fund, the Legacy Club, the Good Neighbour Council, the Queen Elizabeth Hospital Research Foundation, the Royal Commonwealth Society and the Immigration Advisory Council is adequate testimony of this. These offices are signs of a man who gave a lot to his community. They are also the signs of a man who was looked to by his contemporaries for leadership, sound judgment and energy in all his endeavours. It is in this respect that I remember Sir Keith. He was a friendly man; he was a man who gave good advice; he was a man of sound judgment-judgment based on his wide experience.

SPEECH.PARA: But these personal recollections and a listing of Sir Keith's community associations do not pay full tribute to him. Sir Keith played a significant part in the building up of Australia and particularly in the development-both political and economic-of my State of South Australia. The contribution by Sir Keith began very early, while he was in his thirties. He was the founding President of the Political Reform League in South Australia and he led it for nearly 10 years, from 1928 to 1937. This was what one might call nowadays a ginger group that was set up within the old Liberal Federation to modernise and galvanise the Party. Its particular success was in involving amongst its number young city professionals and others who were to go on to play a leading part in the formation in 1932 of the Liberal and Country League (LCL) from a merger of the old Liberal Federation and the Country Party. Quite simply, Sir Keith, through his work in the Political Reform League, was one of the builders of the LCL, the Party that provided such good leadership for South Australia over succeeding decades and which today is transformed as the South Australian division of the Liberal Party.

Secondly, again while still quite young, at the age of about 36, Sir Keith was most active in the formation of the Housing Trust of South Australia. This body provided low cost housing to South Australians and helped keep down the State's cost of living compared with that in other parts of Australia. This was a most important aid to the progressive industrialisation of South Australia, a process that saw the State transformed from a mainly agriculturally based economy into a significant manufacturing centre of the nation. Because of its great success in contributing to the economic development of the State, it is not surprising that all other States eventually followed the lead of South Australia and established their own housing commissions or trusts, but it was my State's particular fortune to be the first to be led down this path by Sir Keith and his contemporaries.

It was again in assisting this process of industrialisation of South Australia that Sir Keith made another valuable contribution. Today the manufacturing industries of South Australia are well established. But in 1937 there was perceived to be a need for government action to ensure the industrialisation of the State and it was here-as a founder member of the Board of the Industries Assistance Corporation of South Australia-that Sir Keith did so much to assist South Australian industry.

Madam Speaker, we remain a small nation with, I believe, our greatest years ahead of us. We are still very much in the business of nation building. Those who go into politics with this as their goal would do well to remember the contribution that Sir Keith Wilson made. In politics, in general community life and in economic development, in adding to the wealth and prosperity of his State and nation, Sir Keith was one who sought to play a part and to do his bit. I conclude by expressing my deep sympathy to Lady Wilson and her family on the death of a great Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this year the Government distributed, through the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), a most significant document aimed at improving, in quality and quantity, the general level of education and training within the Australian community. The title of the document is Skills for Australia. Among other actions seen to be required are the need to raise the level of private sector investment in training and skills formation, the need to improve the employment and training opportunities available to the unemployed and otherwise disadvantaged members of the community, the need to increase the productivity of our education and training resources and the need to evaluate the outputs achieved from the use of those resources. I doubt whether any but the most recalcitrant of reactionaries would disagree with this reading of our needs.

SPEECH.PARA: Because we tend to expect a great emphasis upon exhortations and less upon action to implement programs, I believe that it is instructive to draw attention to efforts that are being made to upgrade existing skills and to broaden the availability of skills already in industry. I therefore draw attention to the Ballarat program called Inskill. Some months ago the Training and Employment Group Ballarat (TEGB), under the executive directorship of Mr Tom Runnalls, conducted comprehensive training needs assessment surveys covering the engineering and hospitality industries in Ballarat. These disclosed a very serious deficiency in the amount and standard of training being made available to industry in the region. There are probably good grounds for suspecting that conditions are similar elsewhere.

In response to a requirement of one of Ballarat's growth industries, the Training and Employment Group Ballarat and the college of technical and further education, the School of Mines and Industries in Ballarat (SMIB), co-operated to develop a program aimed at providing training methods and facilities for new operators. This program was so successful that both the School of Mines and Industries and the Training and Employment Group decided that, by their continuing to work closely together, an effective means could be developed to provide the industrial and commercial training so badly needed. It was this success that led to the establishment of an organisation named Inskill. The two organisations already mentioned were joined by the School of Business Studies of the Ballarat College of Advanced Education (BCAE).

Forming a small management committee in April 1987, Inskill's objective was to introduce, as quickly as possible, effective training initiatives without the problem presented by a highly bureaucratic structure. With TEGB providing seeding funds, the School of Mines and Industries made its facilities available for administration purposes. Inskill has two operating arms, and I quote from an introductory explanatory document produced by the Organisation:
The first is provision of training consultative Services-working with individual firms or organisations to prepare training needs assessments, training plans and procedures, training programmes, etc.

One of our major firms, which is undergoing considerable restructuring in an industry under pressure, is using the program to provide total training needs assessment and a training plan for the next three years. Another leading firm, which has a strong export emphasis, is engaged, through the scheme, in a program of multiskilling. Other local firms are interested in participating in the scheme as well. The second aspect of Inskill's work is the provision of training courses. This involves the development of courses to meet the specific needs of local companies and industries. Courses are conducted in the industry plant or in the education institution itself. Just to indicate the success of the program, I note that 45 companies, representing 500 participants, have co-operated in 40 separate courses.

It will also be instructive for honourable members to learn that, as well as the resources of BCAE and SMIB, Inskill has been able to draw upon the services of the Australian Productivity Council, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Metal Trades Industry Association and other organisations. The success of this program to date, in an area of concern and of great interest to the Government, is providing a practical and direct assistance to underskilled or inappropriately skilled industries and businesses. In keeping with the Government's concern to involve both educational institutions and industry in this process, Inskill is deserving of support, and the contributing organisations our congratulations. I believe that its organisation and methodology will be followed with great interest by similar communities throughout Australia, and I congratulate Tom Runnalls, Peter Shiells, Jack Barker, Bill Burdett, Pat Hope and all those who have been involved in breaking through the barrier of words and putting the plan into effect.

Other countries, such as Botswana and Mozambique, have had the thrust of their moral crusade blunted by economic reality. No other country has implemented this policy. The effect will be that people will still travel from Australia to South Africa but they will do so by a different route.

One can go into an office in Sydney now and book a seat on South African Airways and one will fly Cathay Pacific or Singapore Airlines to Hong Kong, Singapore or Taipei and then catch a South African Airways flight into Johannesburg. So what a joke it all is. One is able to do all this at the same price, $2,064 return, which it used to cost to fly the direct route and one will have an extra exotic city thrown in. The only disadvantage is that if one wants to go straight there it takes eight hours longer. No one will be stranded overseas because 22 national airlines fly into South Africa, all of which are members of the International Air Transport Association. Last year, South African Airways carried 4,000,000 passengers, an increase of 28 per cent, and made 108m rand profit.

Australia will be disadvantaged by this ridiculous decision because of a loss of tourists. Sydney and Perth will lose 220,000 litres of fuel sales a week and air navigation charges of $10,000 a week. The value of 32 beds in Perth hotels a night will be lost. Food suppliers will lose and the crew allowance spending will be forgone. It all adds up to $10m a year. The whole exercise is a charade. It is farcical and childish. It will have no effect except to adversely affect us. Despite all the highsounding rhetoric, no Commonwealth country went along with the decision. The coalition will restore these flights when we return to government after the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most worrying problems that exist in the world today is the increasing harmful effects that pollution of all kinds is causing to the world environment. I have spoken about pollution by radioactive wastes, which continues at an ever-increasing rate as we continue with our process of mining uranium and manufacturing nuclear weapons. We operate nuclear power stations and we reprocess nuclear materials. I assure the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) that I will not talk about that again tonight. I thought he might be worried about that; but he can sit down.

SPEECH.PARA: The pollution caused by chemical wastes arising from the burning of fossil fuels is another major problem. The production of industrial chemicals is also causing major problems. Chlorofluorocarbons are a group of industrial chemicals used as propellants in aerosol cans, as coolants in refrigerators, as liquid cleaners and as plastic foam. The break-up of the chlorofluorocarbons in the atmosphere, after they have escaped from the cans, refrigerators, cleaners and plastics, is causing the breakdown of the ozone layer in our atmosphere. Without the protective ozone layer we are all subjected to the full effects of ultraviolet radiation from the sun, which will cause a rapid increase in the incidents of skin cancer amongst the human population.

The burning of fossil fuels produces mainly carbon dioxide, which acts like the glass of a greenhouse, allowing the warmth of the sun to penetrate to the surface of the earth, but preventing those rays from radiating back into space. The consequence is a warming of the earth to the extent that the climate of whole continents could change, with warmer seas and melting ice caps causing widespread destruction as the seas rise to flood our coastal cities and deserts spread where once fertile plains provided thousands of tonnes of crops and pastures.

In addition, we have a growing number of chemicals, some of which have been used as pesticides, and others which have been used to provide fertilisers to stimulate the growth of our agricultural products. The discovery of dangerous levels of chemical residues in our export meats has led to the subsequent discovery that many hundreds of hectares of land in Australia may be no longer used for growing crops or pastures, as far as can be ascertained, for all time. Many of these chemicals have become pollutants and must now be banned from further use by farmers.

Whilst it is true that scientists and politicians alike have now begun to take action to reduce the harmful effects of ozone destruction and the greenhouse effect of the burning of fossil fuels, and the overuse of chemical fertilisers and pesticides, there is no evidence that we have learnt our lesson from the true cause of pollution of our planet. Pollution is rife because humans are wasting the natural resources of our planet by overuse and by a complete disregard of the fact that those resources, once depleted, cannot be replaced.

In addition, there has been virtually no attempt to reduce the world's human population to a limit which the resources of the planet can sustain. While the advanced industrial nations of the world use energy resources at ever increasing levels, the people of the underdeveloped countries live in primitive conditions of squalor, disease and hunger. The underdeveloped countries look with envy at the developed nations and look forward to the day when they can use electricity, gas, petroleum, coal and nuclear power at the same level as that used by the industrial nations. If all the people of the world were to consume energy at the rate of the industrial nations, the world would become virtually uninhabitable by the middle of the next century.

There is only one answer to the problem I have covered only briefly in this speech-that is, for the industrialised nations to cut back their use of fossil fuels and nuclear power by conserving their energy and by turning to alternative forms of energy generation. Solar power, wind power and tide power are all sources of energy which so far have only been used as limited sources of power. So far the climate of the earth has been able to stabilise itself by self-corrective means over hundreds of millions of years.

The climate of the earth has provided the right balance of temperature and moisture to develop and sustain life. Some species of life have gone into extinction. If the human race is not careful, we will follow the dinosaurs along that path. The danger is that, although we have discovered the scientific method of deciphering the complex changes which occur in our atmosphere, we have not found the method of stopping that pollution.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the shadow Minister for science and energy, I certainly appreciate the remarks made by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). As the shadow Minister for science, matters scientific have certainly captured my thoughts in recent years. It is clear that we need a science culture in Australia. The Government, in its endeavours to make research pay its way, is neglecting the very real need for a renaissance of science in Australia-a science culture that could revitalise out schools and research institutions. An injection of interest in and support of science by government is vital if we are to fashion an environment in which scientific creativity is valued, nourished and allowed freedom of expression.

SPEECH.PARA: The current Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) said in an address last year at Melbourne University that the relations between science and government were improving, and that `Australian science could be poised on the brink of the most important and most productive period in its history'. Nothing could be further from the truth. By September this year the Minister was saying that the Government's focus was too narrow, concentrating on the immediate, the financial and the obvious. How right he is!

What has happened? The 15-year-old Department of Science has been axed with splinters flying in all directions. School students are shunning science and mathematics. A Western Australian study, for example, recently found a 40 per cent decline in the number of top high school students entering maths and science courses. A report commissioned by the Australian Science Teachers Association suggests reasons for this decline. It found that there was a shortage of trained science teachers, that primary teachers have little useful training in science and that many lack a positive attitude to teaching science, and that the amount of time devoted to science is often inadequate.

Government intervention is tightening its central grip on the education system. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is locking his policy advisory bodies into an efficiency agenda. The Australian Council of Trade Unions and big business are to be given a major role in matters affecting schools and higher education. Academics have been relegated to lower level advisory bodies. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Australia's premier research body, is directed to become less science oriented and more applications oriented.

Government charges for part time and external students in higher education are discouraging many able and talented students from undertaking higher education. The Government has declined to increase Commonwealth post graduate awards to the level required by industry and research institutions. Overseas students unable to pay the overseas students charge are threatened with deportation-and this at a time when one in five post-graduate students studying science and engineering is from overseas.

The result of long years of neglect is that only 9 per cent of the work force hold a degree or its equivalent in physics. Australia is graduating only 300 three-year trained, 100 four-year trained and 50 PhD graduates in a year, when it needs 1,000 higher degree physics graduates and 1,700 more first-degree graduates to achieve the Government's goal of increased private sector research.

The catchcry from the Government is relevance. The question is: Can a government recognise, let alone determine, relevance? The attempt by the Government's corporate state apparatus to `pick the winners' in research is likely to be as disastrous as its capacity to pick the winners in industry. At a conference organised by the new Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce earlier this year to select new technologies for the future not one of the 200 top industry, business, academic and government delegates was prepared to select a specific technology. The majority believed this was the role of the market-place-not the Government. The Government, they said, should concentrate on improving the basic infrastructure problems such as poor education, lack of skills, and lack of money for basic research. As Professor Penington pointed out, `fundamental research is an investment in the national intellect.' He went on to say:

If we put all our basic research `eggs' in just a few baskets, we could find in five years' time that we have chosen the wrong baskets and then not have the people, the knowledge, or the international contact which would allow us to catch up.

An examination of case histories shows that the solution to applied problems most often comes out of areas that never would be targeted by assessors of `relevant' research. Who would have thought that nineteenth century studies on the sex cycle of moles would lead to the twentieth century Nobel Prize for the control of cancer? The present focus on Government review and `relevance', when few criteria can be agreed upon, is like putting the cart before the horse or making a car without an engine.

I sound a warning to the Government: it must be careful to maintain a balance between fundamental and relevant research. To do otherwise will do irreparable harm to the Australian science community. Finally, I quote the United Kingdom Committee of Vice Chancellors and Principals which issued the following warning:

There is a tendency for research to be distorted towards glamorous high-tech projects which attract outside funding . . . at the expense of work likely to lead to the greater benefit for the greater number of people.
